docs.lead_paragraph: GETTING driving directions is an easy process these days with computer software, mapping Web sites and G.P.S. systems. They will indeed get you from Point A to Point B, but they often do it in standard English, bland as a news anchor's accent. Whether you're headed for a Brooklyn brownstone or an Indiana office park, the route will be described as a series of intersections and turns. For the vernacular version, inquire at a gas station. In New Jersey, you could be told to pass a jug-handle. In Detroit, you could be advised to take a Michigan left. Texans could tell you to splash through a ford or take a frontage road. People in Kirkland, Wash., will warn you to watch for a pedestrian flag crossing; the city actually provides orange flags to carry in crosswalks to help drivers see walkers.

headline.main: What MapQuest and G.P.S. Don't Tell You Can Get You Lost

docs.abstract: Primer on regional-specific road signs, which can be confusing to drivers; photos; maps (M)
docs.snippet: In a country of homogeneous roads and rules, some regional quirks remain. Have you been on a Jersey Jughandle? Did you ever go right to make a Michigan Left?

docs.lead_paragraph: Ben Popken is an unlikely consumer crusader. He wanted to be a party promoter, running underground music events. In the meantime, he worked at what he described as a shady online firm. To make a little more money -- emphasis on little -- he started a Web site with a scatological name that critiqued advertising campaigns.

They will be scrutinizing an array of moving charts and graphs projected on walls and checking with a team of 30 to 40 engineers for any signs of trouble as Yahoo flips the switch on a new search advertising system.

headline.main: A Long-Delayed Ad System Has Yahoo Crossing Its Fingers

docs.lead_paragraph: When Pony Ma, the 35-year-old co-founder of China's hottest Internet company, sends a message to friends and colleagues, the image that pops up on their screens shows a spiky-haired youth wearing flashy jeans and dark sunglasses. That is not how Mr. Ma actually looks or acts, but it is an image that fits well with the youthful, faintly rebellious nature of a company led by somebody who may be China's closest approximation to Sergey Brin and Larry Page, the young founders of Google. In the two years since Mr. Ma's company, Tencent, went public in Hong Kong, it has grown into a powerhouse that has crushed everyone else in the field.

headline.main: Internet Boom In China Is Built On Virtual Fun

docs.abstract: China's hottest Internet company, Tencent, has greater dominance in its home market than any other Internet company in world, including Google; it was founded in 1998 by college friends in Shenzhen, and led by Ma Huateng, or Pony Ma as he is known in English; its all-in-one packaging of entertainment offerings and mobile instant-messaging service has reached more than 100 million users, or nearly 80 percent of market; its stock price has soared since company went public in Hong Kong; company has market value of $7 billion; America's Internet users send e-mail messages and surf for information, while in China priority for Internet users is entertainment; that could explain why America's biggest Internet companies, like Yahoo, Google and eBay, have largely flopped in China; another distinguishing feature of China's online community is its age: 70 percent are under 30, while in United States 70 percent of online community are over 30; rise of companies like Tencent is worrying Chinese government, which strictly regulates Internet and is wary of Web's ability to mobilize huge online political communities or perhaps to nurture underground economies; photo; graphs (M)
docs.snippet: Instant messaging and game-playing are major obsessions, now central to Chinese culture.

docs.lead_paragraph: AD VIOLENCE AND A ROCK -- No commercial that appeared during Super Bowl XLI directly addressed Iraq, but the war seemed to linger just below the surface of many of them. More than a dozen spots had violent elements. Advertising: Stuart Elliott. [Page C1.] AT YAHOO, A CRITICAL DEBUT -- Project Panama, the much-delayed search-advertising system that Yahoo hopes will close its widening gap with Google, is to start today. Executives will be checking closely with engineers for any sign of trouble in the company's most important new product in years. [C1.] IDENTITY CRISIS FOR DREAMWORKS -- On paper, 2007 is shaping up to be a promising year for DreamWorks, the 12-year-old studio co-founded by the director Steven Spielberg. But on the one-year anniversary of its $1.6 billion sale to Viacom's Paramount, DreamWorks is stinging from a series of perceived slights delivered by its new corporate overseers. [C1.] NEW SUITORS FOR MILLS -- Simon Property Group, the nation's largest mall developer, and the hedge fund Farallon Capital Management are planning a $1.56 billion cash bid for the outlet mall developer Mills Corporation, challenging an agreed-upon deal for Mills to be sold for $1.4 billion to Brookfield Capital Management [C1.] AN I.P.O. FOR RADIO CHIPS -- Applied Digital Solutions is poised to test Wall Street's interest in technology to implant radio chips in humans: this week the company plans an initial public offering of shares in its nascent business VeriChip. The Food and Drug Administration approved sale of the chips in 2004 as a way to track medical history, but only 222 patients have had the device implanted. [C6.] THE VIDEO ANGLE IN SALES -- Online retailers have begun capitalizing on the YouTube craze, offering users a video platform for product demonstrations, rants and raves, sentimental messages and just plain bizarre behavior. E-Commerce Report. [C6.] NEW CHIEF FOR NBC UNIVERSAL -- Jeff Zucker, who made his mark as executive producer of NBC's ''Today'' show, is expected to be named chairman of NBC Universal, succeeding Bob Wright, who has headed the network for 21 years. [C2.] SECURITY IMAGES NO PANACEA -- Site-authentication images, used by financial institutions like Bank of America, ING Direct and Vanguard to enhance security, provide little additional protection, a new study has found. One reason is that customers tend to ignore the images. [C3.] ONLINE AFTER 360 YEARS -- What is said to be the oldest newspaper in the world still in publication, Post och Inrikes Tidningar of Sweden, has gone digital and is now available online, and online only. [C4.] TOBACCO-FREE NEWSWEEK -- Two New York antismoking organizations jointly sponsored an ad offering ''tobacco ad-free'' copies of Newsweek magazine. Newsweek didn't place the ad, but the magazine says it will provide tobacco-ad free copies to any individual subscribers who request them. [C4.] FOR VISTA, NOT MUCH WOW -- Microsoft is said to have committed close to $500 million to marketing Vista, its new operating system. But the Vista release did not generate anything close to the excitement created 12 years ago when Windows 95 was introduced. [C3.] ATTACKS ON MARXIST TEXTS -- An online community that produces and organizes an ever-growing Marxist library says that computer attacks -- primarily from China -- may force the library to stop providing material in Chinese. [C4.] TRIAL AND BOOK TOUR -- Conrad M. Black is scheduled to be in court this spring on charges of criminal fraud and money laundering in Chicago. He'll also be promoting his new biography of Richard M. Nixon, to be published in May. [C4.]

docs.lead_paragraph: IT was just a matter of time. Online retailers have begun capitalizing on the YouTube craze, offering a video platform for product demonstrations, rants and raves, sentimental messages and just plain bizarre behavior. At this point there is little question that the videos, on sites like 1-800-Flowers.com, Buy.com, Blendtec.com and many others soon to come, have novelty value. Whether they will help build customer traffic and sales over the long term, though, remains an open question.

headline.main: Online Sellers Discover The Power of Video Clips

docs.abstract: Online retailers embrace video clips to increase Web traffic and sales; sites like 1-800-Flowers, Buy.com, Blendtec.com and others experiment with product demonstrations, rants and raves and other videos; 1-800-Flowers introduces Video Valentine service where users can upload photos and write messages to loved ones; service links to clips from customers on video-sharing site YouTube; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Online retailers have begun capitalizing on the YouTube craze, offering a video platform for product demonstrations, rants and raves, and just plain bizarre behavior.

docs.lead_paragraph: FOR the teams that play in the Super Bowl, the day after the game is reserved for planning victory parties or promising, ''Wait till next year.'' For Madison Avenue, the day after has become D-Day, given over to discussing and debating the myriad data that become available about the response to the commercials from the game. And while the news was good for some Super Bowl advertisers like Anheuser-Busch and Nationwide Financial, it was unusually bad for the Masterfoods division of Mars. Complaints about its Super Bowl commercial for Snickers candy -- showing two men committing violence against themselves after they accidentally kiss -- led the company to decide late yesterday that it would withdraw the spot.

headline.main: Thanks to the Web, the Scorekeeping On the Super Bowl Has Just Begun

docs.abstract: Visitors to special AOL Web site devoted to Super Bowl advertising spots have streamed them more than 15 million times; there have also been more than 1.6 million unique visitors to ifilm.com since Super Bowl to view commercials there; figures from Akamai Technologies, which is tracking Web site traffic for about two-thirds of marketers that bought spots during game, show that visitors rose steadily from game through Feb 5, meaning that commercials were start of selling process rather than climax; some ads reviewed; photos (L)
docs.snippet: Years ago, Super Bowl spots disappeared after the one or two times they were shown during the broadcast. Today, they have afterlives because of Web sites, blogs and video clips.

docs.lead_paragraph: Everyone suspected that the investors, founders and early employees of YouTube made tidy sums when it was acquired by Google for $1.65 billion in stock late last year. But until yesterday, few knew just how tidy those sums were. The answer, which Google delivered in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, is now in: The sums are big enough to spark a new wave of envy across Silicon Valley.

headline.main: Numbers Are Out on How Rich the YouTube Deal Was

docs.abstract: Google releases figures on payouts from its acquisition of YouTube; show biggest windfalls went to company's three founders and to Sequoia Capital, main financial backer of YouTube; founder and YouTube chief executive Chad Hurley received 694,087 shares of Google and additional 41,232 in trust; shares are worth more than $345 million based on Google's closing price on Feb 7; another founder Steven Chen received 625,366 shares and additional 68,721 in trust, for more than $326 million; Sequoia Capital XI is listed as having 941,027 shares, which are valued at more than $442,000; YouTube third founder Jawed Karim received 137,443 shares worth more than $64 million (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Everyone suspected that the investors, founders and early employees of YouTube made tidy sums when the video sharing site was acquired by Google for $1.65 billion in stock late last year. But until yesterday, few knew just how tidy those sums were. The answer, which Google delivered in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, is now in: The sums are big enough to spark a new wave of envy across Silicon Valley.

docs.lead_paragraph: Remember when Japanese manufacturing techniques were all the rage? You could hardly read the business press without encountering mention of ''lean manufacturing,'' ''just-in-time inventory systems'' and ''total quality management.'' You don't hear much about these ideas anymore, but not because they are no longer in fashion. Quite the reverse is true: the practices have become so widely adopted that they are no longer newsworthy.

headline.main: Kaizen, That Continuous Improvement Strategy, Finds Its Ideal Environment

docs.abstract: Hal R Varian Economic Scene column on Japanese management technique known as kaizen, practice of continuous improvement, that is being used by American executives; says kaizen refers to disciplined process of systematic exploration, controlled experimentation and then painstaking adoption of new procedures; holds most successful online businesses are built on kaizen (M)
docs.snippet: On the Web, continuous improvement really is continuous.

docs.lead_paragraph: WITH Barack Obama expected to announce on Saturday that he's running for president, if you enter ''America,'' ''ready'' and ''black president'' in a Google search, you'll get around 125,000 hits. When pollsters bring up those words with random samples of voters -- and they've done it a lot recently -- they get ''yes'' answers from 62 percent (CNN), 56 percent (Newsweek), 58 percent (Gallup) and 55 percent (CBS). Most of these surveys, however, ask people only if the rest of America is ready for it to happen, not about being ready themselves to make it happen. When one poll asked Republicans and Democrats if they would vote for a ''qualified'' black of their own party, barely 5 percent said no -- hardly surprising, as doing so would be a frank acknowledgment of prejudice.

headline.main: Ready for Obama Already

docs.abstract: Martin Plissner Op-Ed article sees good case that Americans have been ready for some time to elect black president; cites 1996 poll suggesting that Colin Powell would have defeated Pres Clinton if he, rather than Bob Dole, had been Republican nominee (S)
docs.snippet: There is a pretty good, if not quite conclusive, case that America has for some time been ready to elect a black president.

docs.lead_paragraph: Sending Giant Files Q. How can I send a 50-megabyte file to a friend since it's way too big for an e-mail attachment? Are there ways to do it other than burning a CD and using the mail? A. For server space and bandwidth reasons, many e-mail providers limit file attachments on a message to no more that 5 or 10 megabytes in size. This often makes it difficult to send things like high-resolution photographs or digital video files as e-mail attachments.

docs.lead_paragraph: BLACKSTONE TAKES IT -- The takeover battle for Equity Office Properties Trust finally has a winner: the private equity giant the Blackstone Group won with an offer of $55.50 a share, or $39 billion. It is the biggest leveraged private equity buyout ever. [Page A1.] BANK SETTLES TAX SHELTER SUITS -- Deutsche Bank has reached a settlement with hundreds of wealthy investors to whom it sold aggressive tax shelters, a major shift in how it is dealing with the legal woes surrounding its tax shelter work. [C1.] MAKE-YOUR-OWN ADS -- Several companies on the Internet are offering automated ad creation and, in some cases, ad placement services that advertisers can use to create campaigns with little human interaction. Advertising. [C1.] SETTING A TONE -- The new chief of Home Depot, Frank Blake, is beginning to make his mark on an organization. Among other things, he has ended the daily free lunch for his top deputies, and encouraged them to eat with the staffers in the cafeteria. [C1.] YOUTUBE WINDFALL -- The details are in, and the founders, investors and early employees of YouTube received stakes worth up to hundreds of millions of dollars when their video sharing site was acquired by Google for $1.65 billion in stock late last year. [C2.] A RECORD PROFIT AT LAZARD -- Lazard, the investment bank run by Bruce Wasserstein, said that strength in its merger advisory business helped lift its fourth-quarter profit 50 percent, to a record $85.8 million. The news sent Lazard's shares up to their highest level since the firm went public nearly two years ago. [C3.] CASTING A SHADOW -- Airbus executives showed off their new A380, the world's largest passenger aircraft, by taking 200 journalists on a flight above the snow-capped Pyrenees. One initial impression: This plane is big. [C1.] INFRASTRUCTURE WORK ON THE WEB -- VeriSign is undertaking a $100 million expansion of a crucial part of the system that speeds Web surfers to their destinations [C3.] JOB CUTBACKS AT NORTEL -- Nortel Networks, the large but troubled communications equipment maker, said that it would eliminate more than 3,900 jobs in Europe and North America. [C6.] BHP CHIEF LEAVING -- Charles W. Goodyear, below, the Texan who adroitly steered BHP Billiton, the Australian mining company, through China's bull market for resources, said he would leave as chief executive in December as he reported record half-year earnings and a $10 billion stock buyback. [C6.] STORMY DAY ON THE STREET -- Wall Street ended a fractious session only slightly higher, after falling oil prices hurt energy stocks. A Federal Reserve official's comments also soured the market's mood. [C11.] SMALLER PROFIT AT NEWS CORP. -- The News Corporation, Rupert Murdoch's media company, said that quarterly profit fell 24 percent from a year earlier, when it had a one-time gain from asset sales. Revenue rose 18 percent, partly on the box-office hit ''Borat.'' [C6.] DVD SALES HELP DISNEY EARNINGS -- The Walt Disney Company said that first-quarter profit more than doubled on asset sales and income from last year's two biggest-selling DVD releases, ''Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Man's Chest'' and ''Cars.'' [C2.] FINANCING GAP AT GROUND ZERO -- Royal & SunAlliance USA, an insurance company that provided coverage for the World Trade Center, may not be able to pay the $250 million claim that the developer Larry A. Silverstein and the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey say they are owed as a result of the 9/11 terrorist attack. [B3.] AIR CARGO SECURITY -- Democrats in Congress are pushing for a requirement that all air cargo be inspected at a level equal to that of checked baggage, but the Transportation Security Administration said security measures already in place are adequate. [A16.] NONPRESCRIPTION DIET DRUG -- The Food and Drug Administration approved the first officially sanctioned weight loss drug to be sold without a prescription. The drug, Alli, is manufactured by GlaxoSmithKline. [A16.] ONLINE BEAUTIFUL BUT BORED -- Marc Jacobs's sleek fall clothes suggest boredom -- with fashion and with the same old thrills. docs.lead_paragraph: When Google acquired dMarc Broadcasting, a company whose software allows marketers to place ads on radio stations, for up to $1.24 billion early last year, it was seen as a clear sign of Google's ambitions to extend its dominance over Internet advertising to other media. Now, there are indications that Google Audio, as the company's foray into radio advertising is known, has hit some snags. The two brothers who founded dMarc in 2002 have left Google amid growing speculation by analysts and radio and advertising executives that the Internet giant is finding it harder than expected to muscle its way into the radio business.

headline.main: Google Encounters Hurdles In Selling Radio Advertising

docs.abstract: Google, which purchased dMarc Broadcasting early in 2006, is having trouble extending its dominance over Internet advertising to other media, particularly radio; Google is apparently unable to secure enough air time, or inventory, to make software system that allows marketers to place ads on radio stations attractive to advertisers (M)
docs.snippet: There is growing speculation that Google is finding it harder than expected to muscle its way into the radio business.

docs.lead_paragraph: Early in the decade, a struggling Xerox Corporation was trying to sell off a stake in its Palo Alto Research Center, which it could no longer afford to support. But with the technology bubble bursting, the price that investors were willing to pay for a piece of PARC, as the center is known, kept going down. So in 2002, Xerox switched to Plan B: it spun off the center into an independent subsidiary and sought to prove that it could sustain itself by licensing technology and forming partnerships with outside companies.

headline.main: Xerox's Strategy Pays Off With a New Search Venture

docs.abstract: Xerox, which spun off its stake in Palo Alto Research Center in San Francisco in 2002, says strategy is paying off; PARC is licensing broad portfolio of patents and technology to start-up Powerset to build search engine that could some day rival Google (M)
docs.snippet: Xerox’s Palo Alto Research Center is licensing patents and technology to a start-up with the goal of building a search engine that could rival Google.

docs.lead_paragraph: IN our celebrity-studded world, where we make a cult of genius and individual achievement, the mind rebels at the notion that geography trumps personality. Yet the inescapable lesson of the iPod, Google, eBay, Netflix and Silicon Valley in general is that where you live often trumps who you are. Just ask Sim Wong Hoo. About seven years ago, I met Mr. Sim in Singapore, where he was born and was then living. He talked about the rising creativity of Singaporeans and with a flourish, as if to dramatically make his point, he pulled out a prototype of a hand-held music player that he insisted would replace Sony's famous Walkman.

headline.main: When It Comes to Innovation, Geography Is Destiny

docs.lead_paragraph: With the introduction today of getTrio.com, the short-lived but well-loved cable television channel Trio completes its online comeback. Before Trio, which is owned by NBC Universal, stopped broadcasting in January 2006, it was home to original shows like ''Facetime'' with Kurt Andersen and ''Film Fanatic'' with Amy Sedaris. Its companion Web sites, OUTzoneTV.com and BrilliantButCancelled.com, were introduced last June and May and make available some of the programming that appeared on the channel, as well as offering original content.

docs.lead_paragraph: My husband and I are flying to Zurich this spring. We then plan to travel to Geneva and Frankfurt, spending a few days in each city. What is the best way to travel between these or other cities in Europe? When I search Google for information, I am always led to Eurorail, which is very pricey for someone who wants to go to only a couple of places. Are trains easily navigable for English speakers? -- Britt Higgins, New York When you factor in the time spent on transportation to and from airports and check-in, rail, at least in Continental Europe, is the fastest, most comfortable way to travel for distances of up to 200 miles. It may not always be as cheap as the no-frills airlines, but the train takes you between city centers (or between airports and city centers) in more comfort and with less bother -- and you get to enjoy the countryside.

headline.main: Q & A

docs.snippet: A reader would like to know if traveling by train in Europe is the best option for English speakers visiting only a few places.

docs.lead_paragraph: IN real estate, a picture can be worth more than a thousand words. Much, much more. When selling properties online, agents and Web designers say that the pictures buyers see of houses and apartments for sale are often the first -- and sometimes the only -- chance for a seller to make a good impression. Less-than-flattering pictures can turn buyers off and lead to lonely open houses. ''Good photos will grab people's attention and help you sell a home,'' said Jacky Teplitzky, an executive vice president of Prudential Douglas Elliman Real Estate in New York. ''Bad pictures will absolutely give you trouble, because you won't have any calls on it, and nobody will come to see it.''

headline.main: Making Every Pixel Count

docs.abstract: National Assn of Realtors survey says that 80 percent of people across country who bought new home in 2006 used Internet while house hunting and rated photographs as most useful tool in search; agents recommend that photographs be of highest quality possible, with considerations to lighting and furnishings that give best presentation of property; say accessible and well-designed website is critical; photos (M)
docs.snippet: When homeowners want to make the best first impression on the Internet, expertly staged photos are crucial. An easy-to-use Web site helps, too.

docs.lead_paragraph: Ted Stryker, a D.J. at KROQ in Los Angeles, considers it a perk of the job to wear shorts and T-shirts to work. But last Sunday as he dressed for the Grammy Awards, he pulled out his best blazer and a flashy belt buckle, knowing three video cameras would stream live coverage of his show to the Web sites of 147 CBS radio stations. ''What's great about radio is no one knows what you're wearing,'' Mr. Stryker said by telephone as he made his way through the throng at the Grammys. ''I wanted to make myself a little bit more presentable.''

docs.lead_paragraph: A Brussels court ruled Tuesday that Google had violated copyright laws by publishing links to articles from Belgian newspapers without permission. Legal experts said the case could have broad implications in Europe for the news indexes provided by search engines. The ruling, which Google said it would appeal, was hailed by some newspaper industry representatives and may also have an impact on a lawsuit against Google by the news service Agence France-Presse.

Carlos M. Gutierrez, above, the commerce secretary, said that exports were up nearly 13 percent, while Democrats called for a new direction in trade policies.[C1.] RADIO STATIONS GO VIDEO -- The nation's commercial radio stations have seen the future, and it is in video. Tillerson, said that governments should not rush into policies that could damage the global economy in order to limit carbon emissions. [C3.] MALL OWNER PREFERS NEW BID -- The Mills Corporation, the problem-plagued owner of discount shopping and entertainment centers and traditional malls, has spurned its original merger partner and said that it preferred an offer from a partnership led by the Simon Property Group. [C3.] FASTER COMPUTER MEMORY -- I.B.M. researchers say they have set a speed record for a type of computer memory that promises a fundamental performance increase in a coming generation of microprocessors. [C9.] RULING AGAINST AGRICULTURE DEPT. -- A federal judge ruled that the Agriculture Department violated the law by failing to adequately assess possible environmental impacts before approving Monsanto's genetically engineered alfalfa. docs.lead_paragraph: There are two ways to approach our cultural crossroads. You can either wring your hands and lament -- as an eloquent school librarian did recently in The Washington Post -- that literacy today has less to do with Wordsworth or Faulkner and more to do with ''how we find our way through the digital forest of information overload.'' Or you can be a sport about it, slip your earbuds back in and pick up a copy of Pierre Bayard's best-selling ''How to Talk About Books You Haven't Read.'' There is one catch: Professor Bayard writes in French. Of course, that hardly matters as, by definition, you're not going to crack the spine.

docs.lead_paragraph: On Election Night a few months ago, Betsey Stevenson and Justin Wolfers gave a small party for neighbors and colleagues at their row house in Center City in Philadelphia. They connected their television to a projector, served beer and pizza and watched the returns come in. The party went strong until almost midnight, when the results started to seem clear. The Democrats had won the House of Representatives, according to the television networks, but would apparently fall short of capturing the Senate. On MSNBC, Chris Matthews was saying that ''it looks good'' for Senator George Allen, the incumbent in Virginia, whose victory would have ensured a Republican majority. On Fox News, Michelle Malkin reported that a number of blogs had declared Mr. Allen to be the winner.

docs.lead_paragraph: It's fair to say that the relationship between the press and the Bush White House has often been one of mutual suspicion and sometimes outright hostility. And the administration and its allies have at times been outspoken in their belief that the mainstream press was biased against it. But as evidenced by the ''Frontline'' four-part series ''News War,'' whose first episode appears tonight on PBS, government skepticism toward the press is just one of the trials faced by today's news organizations. Those challenges include everything from declining audiences, to the warp speed of the 24/7 news cycle, to the Internet's undercutting the press's monopoly on information, to news operations beholden to conglomerates that sometimes view news as another entertainment portal. The first program in the series, ''Secrets, Spin and the Future of News,'' concentrates in part on White House efforts to manipulate coverage for political ends during the prelude to the Iraq invasion. Virtually the entire hour centers on the ''outing'' of the C.I.A. agent Valerie Plame, whose husband, the former ambassador Joseph C. Wilson IV, had accused the White House, while making its case for war, of knowingly using discredited evidence that Iraq had tried to buy uranium ore from Niger.

headline.main: Spinners, Spinnees and Echoes of Watergate

For online companies, it offers a way to tap local job markets as well as link with highly visible brand names.

docs.lead_paragraph: JEFF ZUCKER, the newly minted chief executive of NBC Universal, ventured to the Times Square headquarters of Viacom two Wednesdays ago with Peter A. Chernin, president of the News Corporation. It was not a social call as much as a social-networking call, to see Philippe P. Dauman, Viacom's chief executive. After all, Viacom had rather publicly ordered YouTube, the Internet's most popular video-sharing site, to remove thousands of clips of MTV material. A few weeks earlier, Viacom had also bowed out of a partnership with NBC and the News Corporation to set up their own alternative to YouTube, which was recently acquired by the search juggernaut Google. Not to be dissuaded, their idea is that a Web start-up featuring the broadcasters' most Web-friendly fare (comedy clips and even whole episodes of their popular shows) could gather a crowd on its own and also be a powerful consortium for licensing content to other destinations around the Web -- including, of course, ''GoogTube.''

docs.lead_paragraph: Gary Bettman, commissioner of the N.H.L. since 1992, has tried to offset low TV ratings by spearheading deals with YouTube.com and Google Video. Fans can now watch highlights and full-length games on the Internet. MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT WHAT MOTIVATED THE LEAGUE TO LOOK FOR ALTERNATIVE MEDIA OUTLETS? -- Young people, particularly in their teens and 20s, are not consuming sports the way my generation did. They are doing lots of things; they are multitasking. They are getting downloads, they are getting alerts on their computers or on their cellphones, and they are consuming sports in a more real-time but less full-time basis. IF YOU COULD CHANGE ONE THING ABOUT THE LEAGUE -- I would hope there would be a greater appreciation by casual sports fans of the incredible skill and passion of our players. WHAT ARE YOU READING? -- I just finished reading ''Manhunt,'' which was about John Wilkes Booth's attempt to escape after his assassination of President Lincoln, and prior to that I read ''Team of Rivals.'' FAVORITE MOVIE? -- It is in the genre of ''Goodfellas'' and ''The Godfather.'' HOW DO YOU GET SPORTS NEWS? -- Everywhere. I read multiple papers. I am online. I watch television.

docs.lead_paragraph: So many exhibitions have been devoted to landscape in New Jersey that one more might seem redundant, but the scale and pace of real estate development in cities like Jersey City, Asbury Park and Newark have perhaps made the subject fresh again. ''Landscape Revisited: Fact and Metaphor,'' split between City Without Walls and the Seton Hall University School of Law, revisits this theme. Organized by Peter Homitzky, a Hoboken-based landscape painter, the exhibition is a sprawling survey of the proliferation of contemporary landscape imagery. The work itself, by 19 artists, mostly takes the New Jersey landscape as its point of departure, even though only about half of the artists live in the state. The others are from New York City and elsewhere.

docs.lead_paragraph: European governments are preparing legislation to require companies to keep detailed data about people's Internet and phone use that goes beyond what the countries will be required to do under a European Union directive. In Germany, a proposal from the Ministry of Justice would essentially prohibit using false information to create an e-mail account, making the standard Internet practice of creating accounts with pseudonyms illegal.

headline.main: Europe's Plan to Track Phone and Net Use

docs.abstract: European governments are preparing legislation to require companies to keep detailed data about people's Internet and phone use that goes beyond European Union requirements; EU countries have until 2009 to put Data Retention Directive into law but some people involved in issue are concerned about shift in policy concerning privacy rights (M)
docs.snippet: A proposed law would require companies to keep detailed data about people’s Internet and phone use.

docs.lead_paragraph: The online version of VG, the biggest-selling tabloid newspaper in Norway, had the latest news flashes on the death of Anna Nicole Smith, of course. But a little down the page was something else -- oil company earnings reports. The financial headlines link readers to E24, an online business ''newspaper.'' Not many tabloids feature business fare on their front pages, and perhaps even fewer papers willingly direct readers to other publications. But E24 and VG (or Verdens Gang, which means ''the way of the world'') are both owned by Schibsted, an Oslo newspaper publisher that does things differently on the Internet.

headline.main: While Others Struggle, Norwegian Newspaper Publisher Thrives on the Web

docs.abstract: Norwegian tabloid newspaper VG thrives on Internet while other newspapers struggle to make profit; online operations will generate 20 percent of company's revenue this year after 28 percent rise in fourth quarter earnings; early entry into online space has put publication in better position than rivals; Kjell Aamot, chief executive of parent company Schibsted, cites willingness to change business model as reason for success; photos (M)
docs.snippet: Schibsted, which owns the biggest-selling tabloid in Norway, is now the biggest player on the Internet in Norway and neighboring Sweden.

docs.lead_paragraph: ONLINE coupons have always been a bargain-hunter's diversion, which may be precisely why the market has grown so slowly. Who wants to take time out of the day to track down sites that give away 50-cent discounts, then search for eligible products that they might need? Right now, the practice appeals only to about 12 percent of the 175 million Internet users in the United States, according to ComScore Media Metrix. The rest are apparently happy getting coupons in their Sunday paper, where they can flip through them in seconds.

headline.main: From Clipouts to the Web, Coupons Transition Slowly

docs.abstract: Appeal of online coupons has been slow to catch on with consumers but may soon become more popular as companies find new ways to introduce savings; Coupons Inc, which runs Coupons.com, will work with product manufacturers to integrate online coupons with consumers' Web-surfing; software and services improve as companies search for ways to match coupon-clipping experience; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Online coupons have always been a bargain-hunter’s diversion, which may be precisely why the market has grown so slowly.

docs.lead_paragraph: Two years ago, Sami Grover, an environmentally minded Englishman, vowed to take his last trip by airplane. Then a summer romance in North Carolina turned into a long-distance love affair -- and then into months of busy trans-Atlantic travel. To compensate for the tons of greenhouse gases the couple's plane trips helped spew into the atmosphere, Mr. Grover quietly began paying Climate Care, a British company, to help make the world a little greener for him and his girlfriend.

headline.main: Guilt-Free Pollution. Or Is It?

docs.abstract: Article in series Energy Challenge: The Carbon Offset Game focuses on whether efforts by pop stars, chief executives and politicians to offset carbon emissions are really effective; holds scientists and environmental watchdogs say carbon trading actually may be producing little of real value to environment; holds some carbon-offset firms have begun to acknowledge that certain investments like tree-planting may be ineffective, and they are shifting their focus to what they say is reliable activity, like wind turbines, cleaner burning stoves, or buying up credits that otherwise would allow companies to pollute; photos (M)
docs.snippet: Pop stars, chief executives and politicians vaunt how they offset carbon emissions by planting trees or investing in renewable energy projects.

docs.lead_paragraph: The plan, hatched for months in the arid mountains of North Africa, was to attack the American and British Embassies here. It ended in a series of gun battles in January that killed a dozen militants and left two Tunisian security officers dead. But the most disturbing aspect of the violence in this normally placid, tourist-friendly nation is that it came from across the border in Algeria, where an Islamic terrorist organization has vowed to unite radical Islamic groups across North Africa.

headline.main: North Africa Feared as Staging Ground for Terror

docs.abstract: Second of two articles, Terrorists Resurgent, on efforts of violent Algerian group Salafist Group for Preaching and Combat (GSPC) to organize extremists across North Africa and join remnants of Al Qaeda into new international force for jihad; American and European counterterrorism officials fear North Africa could become Afghanistan-like terrorist hinterland within easy striking distance of Europe; threat is also real for US because of visa-free travel to American cities for most European passport holders; GSPC has survived more than decade of Algerian government attempts to eradicate it, and is now best-organized and -financed terrorist group in region; on fifth anniversary of 9/11 attacks, Al Qaeda named GSPC as its representative in North Africa and group switched its name to Al Qaeda of the Islamic Maghreb, reportedly on orders of Osama bin Laden; GSPC's creation and brutal history detailed; it is said to be forging links with terrorist groups in Morocco, Nigeria, Mauritania, Tunisia and elsewhere; photos; map (L)
docs.snippet: A brutal Algerian group with a long history of violence is suspected of organizing a new force for jihad in Tunisia.

docs.lead_paragraph: By the end of February, most of the employees at eBay's San Jose headquarters will collect their possessions, wave a final goodbye to their landline telephones and change cubicles. But what John Donahoe, president of one of eBay's most important divisions, really wants is for his colleagues to change the way they work. ''I'm a big fan of breaking patterns,'' he said.

headline.main: Stirring Up the Cubicles at eBay; Executive Aims to Reinvigorate the Web Auction Business

docs.abstract: Article on John Donahoe, president of eBay Marketplaces, focuses on his efforts to wean employees off their landline telephones and getting them to use Internet calling service Skype, which eBay acquired for $2.6 billion in 2005; graph; photos (L)
docs.snippet: John Donahoe tries to make eBay easier to use for its shoppers and sellers  and more attractive to investors.

docs.lead_paragraph: When half a dozen students in Neil Waters's Japanese history class at Middlebury College asserted on exams that the Jesuits supported the Shimabara Rebellion in 17th-century Japan, he knew something was wrong. The Jesuits were in ''no position to aid a revolution,'' he said; the few of them in Japan were in hiding. He figured out the problem soon enough. The obscure, though incorrect, information was from Wikipedia, the collaborative online encyclopedia, and the students had picked it up cramming for his exam.

headline.main: A History Department Bans Citing Wikipedia As a Research Source

docs.abstract: History department at Middlebury College in Vermont bans citing information obtained from Wikipedia online encyclopedia after several students obtained incorrect information from Website and used it to support research in their papers; falls short of forbidding students from visiting site at all; says students should not be using research from any encylopedias to write their papers; Wikipedia entries are collaborative efforts by hundreds of volunteers; articles are subject to mistakes and sometimes deliberate falsehoods; use of Wikipedia is being debated by other universities; photos (S)
docs.snippet: Middlebury College has jumped into a growing debate within journalism, the law and academia over what respect, if any, to give Wikipedia articles.

docs.lead_paragraph: Fox Interactive Media, the unit of News Corporation that operates the Web site MySpace, said yesterday that it had acquired the Strategic Data Corporation, an advertising technology company based in Santa Monica, Calif., to help increase revenue from the popular social networking site. Fox Interactive plans to use Strategic Data's technology and 14 employees to bolster its profit from MySpace, which attracts billions of page views every month. Terms of the acquisition were not disclosed.

docs.lead_paragraph: A WEEK before Viacom announced that it would make video content available online through a site called Joost, the Viacom-owned MTV Networks said that it would soon allow other Web sites to embed video clips from its own sites: MTV.com, VH1.com, Comedycentral.com, BET.com and others. ''We need to open up our Web sites and content both for consumers and for other companies,'' Mika Salmi, MTV Networks' president of global digital media, told Reuters, which said the move was ''part of a strategy to bring Viacom's Web sites up to 'Web 2.0' standards'' (reuters.com).

docs.lead_paragraph: THE term ''very GQ'' entered the vernacular long ago, evoking sartorial splendor or stylish behavior. Now, the magazine that inspired the phrase is hoping to redefine it by declaring that you are never fully dressed without a social conscience. To help commemorate its 50th anniversary this year, GQ magazine is starting a charitable project called the Gentlemen's Fund. The initiative is centered on a Web site that is planned to go live today, thegentlemensfund.com. It will also involve the GQ Mobile text-messaging service and events at stores like Saks Fifth Avenue.

headline.main: GQ Hopes to Make the 'G' Stand for Generosity

docs.abstract: Stuart Elliott Advertising column on Gentlemen's Fund, charitable project started by GQ magazine to help commemorate its 50th anniversary; spokesman, singer John Legend, will encourage visitors to thegentlemensfund.com Web site to make donations, buy merchandise from particular marketers and participate in eBay auctions; project is example of cause-related marketing, which is becoming increasingly popular; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Burnishing the image of a brand or company by forging ties with a philanthropy or charity is becoming increasingly popular on Madison Avenue.

docs.lead_paragraph: VMware, a young Silicon Valley company, is the early leader in a fast-growing market for what is called virtual-machine software. And that puts it on a collision course with Microsoft, the industry's Goliath. A virtual machine essentially mimics a computer so that several copies of an operating system -- say, Windows or Linux or both -- can run on one physical machine. It allows computing chores to be done on fewer computers, using less electricity and taking up less space, promising a way to control costs at corporate data centers straining to keep up with the ever-increasing demands of the Internet age.

headline.main: A Software Maker Goes Up Against Microsoft

docs.abstract: VMware, early leader in fast-growing market for virtual-machine software, is preparing to issue white paper detailing its concerns that license changes by Microsoft limits ability to move virtual-machine software around data centers to automate management of computing work; VMware is making no antitrust claims against Microsoft and legal experts question whether friction between companies is anything more than rivalry; photo; graph (M)
docs.snippet: VMware is the early leader in a fast-growing market for virtual-machine software, putting it on a collision course with Microsoft.

docs.lead_paragraph: Google built an empire delivering advertisements across the Internet, and now it plans to distribute content from media companies just as aggressively. Google is working with Dow Jones & Company, Condé Nast, Sony BMG Music Entertainment and other large content companies to syndicate their video content on other Web sites. The videos appear inside Google ad boxes on sites that are relevant to the content of the videos, and advertisements run during or after the content. Google shared the ad revenue with the video provider and with the sites that show the videos.

docs.lead_paragraph: THE World Wide Web is awash in digital video, but too often we can't find the videos we want or browse for what we might like. That's a loss, because if we could search for Internet videos, they might become the content of a global television station, just as the Web's hypertext, once it was organized and tamed by search, became the stuff of a universal library.

headline.main: Millions of Videos, and Now a Way to Search Inside Them

docs.snippet: Blinkx, a start-up in San Francisco, has created a video search method, a kind of remote control for Web videos.

docs.lead_paragraph: NEW FINANCE CHIEF AT CITIGROUP -- Gary L. Crittenden, an American Express executive, has been named Citigroup's chief financial officer, a post that puts him on a path to succeed Charles O. Prince III, its chairman and chief executive. [Page C1.] STILL SETTING BUYOUT RECORDS -- Henry R. Kravis, whose role in the RJR Nabisco buyout was the inspiration for ''Barbarians at the Gates,'' is at it again, with a proposed $45 billion buyout of TXU. [C1.] A CHALLENGER IN WEB ADS -- In the competition for those small sponsored ad links that run adjacent to related articles online, both Yahoo and Google are facing a challenge from a tiny adversary named Quigo Technologies, which operates an ad service that bills itself as an alternative to the giants. [C1.] AN UNLIKELY INTERNET STAR -- Shmuel Tennenhaus, an aspiring comedy writer who gained a modest following on YouTube for his droll question-and-answer clips and other spots featuring his grandmother ''Bubby,'' is being wooed by the site's competitors with promises of guaranteed exposure, a share of advertising money, or both. [C1.] A LITTLE HELP FROM HER FRIENDS -- Tila Tequila, left, a onetime model for Playboy.com who was born Tila Nguyen, became famous last year for having the most friends on MySpace.com. Now she's hoping to translate her virtual fame into a real music career. [C4.] YOU, TOO, CAN HAVE MANY PALS -- Users of MySpace.com and similar sites may soon be able to hire ''friends'' for money. [C4.] GOOGLE MOVES INTO DISTRIBUTION -- Google is working with Dow Jones, Condé Nast, Sony BMG Music and other large content companies to syndicate some of their video content on other Web sites. [C6.] POSSIBLE SUITOR FOR TRIBUNE -- The Tribune Company is weighing a proposal from Sam Zell, the Chicago billionaire who sold his office development firm earlier this month for $39 billion in the biggest leveraged buyout ever. [C2.] VIDEO GAMES IN THE THEATER -- A hybrid theater in Madrid blends the seating capacity of a movie theater with the digital fire and fury of a video game. And naturally, there's buttered popcorn. [C4.] A LESSON FOR LAWMAKERS -- As the new Congress experiments with the wide world of blogging and hosting video clips, members are learning the complexities of copyright law, much the way the casual YouTube user has learned that there are corporations out there who own ''Lost'' and can stop you from posting a favorite episode. [C4.] BUYING VIDEO FROM BITTORRENT -- The peer-to-peer pioneer BitTorrent, whose technology unleashed a wave of illegal file-sharing on the Internet, plans a digital media store that will offer thousands of movies, television shows, PC games and music videos each, all legally available for purchase. ''I think what consumers want is a good experience,'' said BitTorrent's chief executive, Bram Cohen, above, ''and the first part of that is making the content they want available legitimately.'' [C5.] NEW DIRECTION IN CHIPS -- Under industry standards, almost all semiconductor chips today have wires that run only along horizontal and vertical axes, not diagonally. But a maker of software tools has made it possible to route lines diagonally as well, which will add to the speed, efficiency and performance of a generation of smaller chips. [C5.] SATELLITE RADIO MERGER -- Washington will take its first look at the proposed merger of XM and Sirius on Wednesday when a House committee meets. But regardless of what Congress thinks about the merger, the satellite radio business is facing huge changes. [C3.] NIKE COMMISSIONING SONGS -- To mark the 25th anniversary of its Air Force 1 sneaker, Nike has commissioned a song from some prominent hip-hop musicians and is selling it on iTunes. The song, ''Better Than I've Ever Been,'' is about perseverance, a theme Nike supplied. [C4.] CANADIAN RAIL STRIKE ENDS -- The Canadian National Railway's striking employees are returning to work after a two-week strike that delayed shipments of coal, grains, lumber and car parts for companies like Ford Motor. [C2.] AWARD FOR TIMES PHOTOGRAPHER -- Tyler Hicks, a staff photographer for The New York Times, was named the newspaper photographer of the year by the Missouri School of Journalism's Pictures of the Year International contest. [C2.]

docs.lead_paragraph: How important is college to Americans? docs.lead_paragraph: Random House has introduced a search tool on its Web site that will make available a small portion of text from 5,000 of its new and backlist titles, the company announced yesterday. As much as 10 percent of each book, typically a front cover, introduction and first chapter, will be accessible on the Random House Web site (randomhouse.com) by clicking on the individual book and entering keywords. Several thousand more titles will be added to the database this spring, and the company hopes to eventually allow searching across all books, rather than just within an individual title. Publishers have been scrambling to compete with Google Book Search and Amazon, which both offer free digitized book content. HarperCollins introduced a similar browsing tool on its Web site (harpercollins.com) last week. JULIE BOSMAN

headline.main: YouTube Discovers It Has Friends in League Offices

docs.snippet: The National Basketball Association announced a deal with the video-sharing site to create an authorized N.B.A. channel and sanction fans’ uploads.

docs.lead_paragraph: HIGH FLYING -- More people are going abroad in style. International premium travel -- that is, first-class and business-class flying -- grew 4.3 percent last year compared with 2005, according to the International Air Transport Association. Premium travel on the trans-Atlantic routes, which represent 16.1 percent of international premium traffic (the biggest proportion when travel within Europe is not counted) rose 7.8 percent in December compared with December 2005, and rose an overall 3.5 percent for the year. Premium traffic on Europe to Asia routes and all routes to the Middle East continued to grow in double digits, said the group, which represents 250 world airlines. Worldwide there were about 2.1 billion passengers in 2006, and 10.5 percent of them flew premium classes, the group said. HIT LIST -- The top 10 online travel sites in January, based on the number of visits to 20 sites, were these: MapQuest (11.94 percent market share); Expedia (4.62 percent); Yahoo Maps (4.04 percent); Travelocity (2.92 percent); Southwest Airlines (2.87 percent); Orbitz (2.76 percent); Cheap Tickets (2.60 percent); Google Maps (2.02 percent) Yahoo Travel (1.3 percent) and American Airlines (1.28 percent). That is according to Hitwise, an Internet usage research company. RENOVATIONS IN LOS ANGELES -- There was a groundbreaking ceremony at Los Angeles International Airport yesterday for a $575.6 million renovation of the Tom Bradley International Terminal. Officials said the renovation to the 1 million-square-foot terminal was needed to help the airport compete with airports like San Francisco International as demand surges for trans-Pacific travel. Some ticket and check-in counters and screening gates will be relocated during the three-year project, but airport officials said that they expected there would be no disruptions in flight operations. When the renovations are complete, airport officials said, four new megalounges will replace the 16 individual airline lounges and significantly expand overall lounge space by 72 percent, to 47,000 square feet. Three of the new lounges will serve airline alliances, and the fourth will serve unaffiliated airlines. ET CETERA -- About $10 billion a year is spent by 12- to 18-year-olds traveling without their parents, usually on a school or other group trip, but sometimes traveling independently, according to a new survey by the Student and Youth Travel Research Institute at Michigan State University. Thanks to booming travel demand, the two major manufacturers of commercial airliners, Boeing and Airbus, are ''sitting on enormous production backlogs,'' said the Center for Asia Pacific Aviation. Airbus currently has 2,533 outstanding orders, and Boeing has 2,434. ''And production lines for many models are essentially sold out for the next two or three years,'' the trade group said. JOE SHARKEY

docs.lead_paragraph: Microsoft's drive into the health care market is just getting under way, but the company signaled yesterday that one important ingredient in its plan will be a specialized search engine tailored to deliver useful medical information to consumers. Microsoft is buying Medstory Inc., a small start-up in Foster City, Calif. Its search software applies artificial intelligence techniques to medical and health information in medical journals, government documents and on the Internet.

headline.main: Microsoft to Buy Health Information Search Engine

docs.abstract: Microsoft is buying Medstory Inc, small start-up in Foster City, Calif; Medstory's search software applies artificial intelligence techniques to medical and health information in medical journals, government documents and on Internet; financial terms undisclosed (M)
docs.snippet: Microsoft says its purchase of Medstory is part of an effort to build a suite of tools and services related to health care.

docs.lead_paragraph: Niklas Zennstrom and Janus Friis made names for themselves as renegade Internet entrepreneurs by taking conventional tasks like talking on the phone or listening to music and giving consumers an unconventional -- and free -- way to do it. Sometimes that meant pushing legal boundaries.

headline.main: Internet Renegades Go by the Book

docs.abstract: Niklas Zennstrom and Janus Friis, who made names for themselves as renegade Internet entrepreneurs by taking conventional tasks like talking on phone or listening to music and giving consumers unconventional way to do it, are doing everything by book with its new creation called Joost, Web video venture; revenue-sharing agreements have been signed and licenses have been granted; Joost has reached agreements to broadcast programs from Viacom networks like MTV, Comedy Central and VH1; financial terms have not been disclosed, but Viacom and Joost will share advertising revenue; Joost-Viacom partnership gives Viacom degree of control over its programming that it has been unable to obtain so far from video-sharing Web site YouTube; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Joost, the new Web video venture of Niklas Zennstrom and Janus Friis, has struck the mother lode of television programming through its deal with Viacom.

docs.lead_paragraph: Google disclosed in its 2006 annual report on Thursday that the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission nearly a year ago had called into question how it accounted for income taxes. In the annual filing, Google said it received a letter from the S.E.C. in March 2006 on various issues and subsequently corresponded with the agency as recently as January 2007. The tax dispute remains unresolved.

docs.lead_paragraph: Google has been frustrated in its efforts to reach comprehensive deals with major studios and networks to put their video on YouTube. But in the meantime, it is forming partnerships with hundreds of smaller media companies that see value -- or at least a valuable experiment -- in contributing to the site. Some of the partnerships have been announced publicly. On Monday, for instance, YouTube, which was purchased by Google in October, said it had teamed up with the National Basketball Association to create a channel where the league would show authorized clips and where fans could upload short videos showcasing their best moves.

headline.main: Google Courts Small YouTube Deals, and Very Soon, a Larger One

docs.abstract: YouTube, which was purchased by Google in October, has teamed up with National Basketball Association to create channel where league will show authorized clips and where fans can upload short videos showcasing their best moves; YouTube has reached deal with independent label, Wind-up Records, to stream music videos and allow YouTube users to incorporate music tracks into their own videos; YouTube will announce partnership with BBC to create two entertainment channels and one news channel on YouTube; two of channels will include ads placed by Google's advertising system, known as AdSense; company has firmed up more than 1,000 partnerships with content owners ranging from Sundance Channel to small independent video producers (M)
docs.snippet: YouTube is set to announce a partnership with the BBC to create two entertainment channels and one news channel on YouTube.

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-10 Top Taliban Member Is Said To Be Captured in Pakistan The former Taliban defense minister was arrested in Pakistan on Monday, the day of Vice President Dick Cheney's visit, two Pakistani officials said. The man, Mullah Obaidullah, was a senior leader of the Afghan insurgency, which has battled American and NATO forces with increasing intensity over the last year, and is the most important Taliban member to be captured since the American-led invasion of Afghanistan. A1 Ahmadinejad to Visit Saudi King President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad of Iran will visit Saudi Arabia for a landmark meeting with King Abdullah intended to tackle the growing sectarian and political crises wracking the Middle East, Iranian officials said. A9 Bomb Kills 7 at Iraq Wedding A car bomb that was apparently aimed at a policeman's wedding party in Falluja killed seven guests and wounded six, the local police said. Locals said the attack appeared to be part of a battle between insurgents and other groups. A8 A New, and Feared, Top Chechen President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia appointed Ramzan A. Kadyrov, a widely feared young official whose security forces have been accused of kidnappings, torture and other abuses, to be president of Chechnya, the battered southern republic. A6 South Korea Resists Chinatown While the growing wealth of both Chinese and overseas Chinese has given birth to new Chinatowns in places as varied as Las Vegas, Dubai and Belgrade, plans for a chinatown in South Korea have been fraught with historical subtexts and have not progressed very far. A3 NATIONAL A11-15 Army Dismisses General Over Hospital Conditions The two-star general in charge of Walter Reed Army Medical Center was relieved of command after disclosures that wounded soldiers being treated as outpatients were living in dilapidated quarters and enduring long waits for treatment. A1 Views on Health Care A majority of Americans say the federal government should guarantee health insurance to every American, especially children, and are willing to pay higher taxes to do it, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll. A1 California Gains Attention While the 2008 presidential campaign is well under way in traditional bellwether states, candidates are also making an early run at voters in California, a delegate-rich but typically sidestepped state. A15 Deadly Tornado Hits Southeast A storm system that stretched nearly 1,000 miles from the Midwest to the Southeast killed at least eight people in two states, including five who died when an apparent tornado caused the roof to collapse at a high school in Enterprise, Ala., state emergency management officials said. A13 SCIENCE/HEALTH Children's Medicine Examined Federal drug regulators have started a broad review of the safety of cough and cold remedies meant for children, a top official said. A1 NEW YORK/REGION B1-6 Citing Rent Concerns, U.S. Rejects Starrett Deal The federal housing secretary has rejected the proposed $1.3 billion sale of Starrett City, a working-class enclave of 46 buildings in Brooklyn, because the prospective buyer has failed to supply adequate financial information or a plan for how the complex would remain ''a viable community for New Yorkers of modest means.'' A1 Counseling for Sex Offenders New York's new guidelines for detaining sex offenders who have completed their prison sentences go beyond confining the most violent predators: they also provide mental health counseling and treatment to inmates while they are jailed or confined and provide supervision and treatment after their release. B1 More Restaurants Closed New York City shut 13 fast food restaurants operated by the same franchisee that owns the Greenwich Village KFC/Taco Bell where swarms of rats were found. B1 BUSINESS DAY C1-10 Paper Mills in a Trade Case American paper mills have become a test case for a possible confrontation between the United States and China that many industry officials and members of Congress hope will lead to new tariffs on steel, furniture, textiles and plastics. A1 Google Finds Another Way Google has been frustrated in its efforts to reach comprehensive deals with major studios and networks to put their video on YouTube. C1 Business Digest C2 EDITORIAL A16-17 Editorials: A suddenly convenient truth; ground zero victims; the path to citizenship; Robert B. Semple Jr. on a historian's valedictory. Columns: Paul Krugman, Thomas L. Friedman. SPORTSFRIDAY C10-13 Chinese athletes Gao Wei, Ding Long and Shen Yalei knew nothing about football last summer, when they were selected by the N.F.L. at a tryout in China. Now they are immersed in a crash course on kicking footballs -- and the league is hoping one of them can provide international appeal in Asia. C10 Crossword E35 TV Listings E25 Weather C10

docs.lead_paragraph: COUNT THE REASONS -- A caldron of investors' concerns -- from a slowing American economy to a faltering mortgage market and the tightening of historically easy credit -- has been bubbling up over the last year and appears to have set off the wave of selling that rocked world financial markets this week. [Page C1.] INSIDER TRADING SCHEME CITED -- Federal authorities accused 13 people of taking part in what they called one of the most far-reaching insider trading schemes on Wall Street in decades, involving investment banks and a web of hedge funds, day traders, lawyers and even a few supervisors. [C1.] DEFENDING AGAINST CHINA TRADE -- A paper mill in Maryland's Appalachians, the area's last remaining big factory, may become a line in the sand as the Commerce Department decides whether to impose duties on high-gloss paper -- the kind made at the mill -- that is imported from China. [A1.] PROTECTIONISM'S TOLL -- Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr. said that the economy was slowing toward moderate and sustained growth, but warned it could be derailed if trade barriers were raised.[C7.] WAL-MART'S FOCUS -- ''Saving people money so they can live better lives.'' This new, and so far internal, definition of what Wal-Mart, the nation's largest retailer, stands for will soon become a very public strategy, evident on the shelves of 4,000 stores and in advertisements seen across the country. [C1.] ROUGH QUARTER FOR DELL -- Dell's inability to capture sales in the booming notebook computer market was reflected in its fourth-quarter financial results. Dell said net income fell by a third, and revenue fell 5.1 percent. The last time revenue declined at Dell was in 2001, in the recession that followed the technology boom. [C3.] YOUTUBE'S PARTNERSHIPS -- Google has been frustrated in its efforts to reach comprehensive deals with major studios and networks to put their video on YouTube, but it is forming partnerships with hundreds of smaller media companies [C1.] JOB OPENING IN OMAHA -- Warren Buffett, chairman of Berkshire Hathaway, said in his letter to shareholders that he is seeking a new candidate to become chief investment officer when he steps down. [C3.] CHEVY TRUCK EDGES F-SERIES -- General Motors surprised the auto industry by posting a sales increase in February, when its new Chevrolet Silverado pickup unseated the Ford F-series for the title of best-selling vehicle. [C3.] RETAILERS IN DIFFERENT DIRECTIONS -- Sears Holdings and Kohl's both reported higher quarterly earnings, but the struggling retailer Gap Inc. reported that its fourth-quarter profit fell 35 percent. ''We were not satisfied with our 2006 results and are taking action,'' said Gap's chairman, Robert J. Fisher, above, who is serving as the company's interim chief executive [C6.] EUROPEANS VS. MICROSOFT -- The European Commission has threatened Microsoft with millions of euros in new fines in a long-running antitrust dispute, saying the company was demanding unreasonable royalties from rivals seeking to link their software to the Windows operating system. [C3.] EARNINGS PLUNGE FOR TELEKOM -- Deutsche Telekom, the largest European telephone company, posted a fourth-quarter loss of nearly 900 million euros ($1.18 billion) as it lost customers in its home market, prompting the company to look abroad for growth. [C2.] TV SCREENS EVERYWHERE -- Digital TV networks are popping up on screens in groceries, office buildings, retail stores, on gas pumps, and, well, just about every place imaginable. Advertisers are trying to reach consumers where they cannot avoid ads. Advertising. [C6.] DOING GOOD, IN PINSTRIPES -- Hedge funds are known for secrecy and a ruthless focus on profitability. But there is a growing number of charities within the $1.3 trillion world of hedge funds. [C5.] RATS' IMPACT -- New York City officials shut three Pizza Hut restaurants operated by the same franchisee that owns the KFC/Taco Bell in Manhattan that became infamous when television cameras captured a swarm of rats inside. Yum Brands, the parent company of Taco Bell, KFC and Pizza Hut, said it was closing 10 other restaurants owned by the franchisee. [B1.] CHILDREN'S COLD REMEDIES -- Federal drug regulators have started a broad review of the safety of popular cough and cold remedies meant for children, according to a top official. [A1.] ONLINE Business Briefing Articles on these developments are at nytimes.com/business. Rural telephone carriers must connect calls made by voice-over-Internet Protocol customers, the Federal Communications Commission ruled in a decision that breaks down one of the last barriers to allowing VoIP to compete fully with traditional phone carriers. (DOW JONES) The American International Group posted fourth-quarter earnings nearly eight times higher than a year ago, with property and casualty insurance its star performer. (REUTERS) EchoStar Communications Corporation said that its fourth-quarter profit rose 15 percent as a result of an increase in subscribers. (AP) Deloitte Touche Tohmatsu, one of the world's largest accounting firms, nominated James. H. Quigley to be chief executive, succeeding William G. Parrett, who plans to step down at the end of May. (NYT)

headline.main: Thanks to the Internet, We'll Always Have Paris

docs.lead_paragraph: Next week Cisco Systems, a Silicon Valley heavyweight, plans to announce one of its most unusual deals: it is buying the technology assets of Tribe.net, a mostly forgotten social networking site, according to people close to the companies' discussions. It is a curious pairing. Cisco, with 38,000 employees, makes networking equipment for telecommunications providers and other big companies. Tribe.net, run by a company with eight employees, has been trampled by newer social sites like MySpace and Facebook.

headline.main: Social Networking's Next Phase

docs.lead_paragraph: This week private preschools will send out their coveted acceptance letters to anxious parents. We've enjoyed every step of the admissions process over these last six months -- from the speed-dial excitement of the post-Labor Day calls for an application to camping out on the sidewalk overnight for the open house. We see it as a real testament to the strength of your program that 98 percent of your spots for next year will be filled with siblings. The company BermanBraun will supply shows to NBC on a ''first look'' basis, meaning that NBC will get the first opportunity at any idea they develop. [C6.] NEW 'NIGHTLY NEWS' PRODUCER -- Alexandra Wallace, a vice president of the news division who has had broad oversight for ''The NBC Nightly News with Brian Williams'' since January of last year, is the program's new executive producer. Buchmueller is selling homeowners insurance in Florida and other coastal states at as little as half the going rates, but only to those owning high-end homes of a certain age and size. [C3] TAPING CALLS -- Federal investigators are looking into what Wal-Mart Stores said was the secret taping by a computer systems technician of conversations between a reporter for The New York Times and members of the company's media relations department. [C1.] BLACKSTONE BUYS A LOT OF WAX -- The Blackstone Group has agreed on to purchase the Tussauds Group, owner of the Madame Tussauds wax museums. [C1.] PAYOLA SETTLEMENT -- Four of the largest radio station owners in the United States have agreed to pay $12.5 million to resolve payola claims in a settlement with the Federal Communications Commission. [C1.] SELLING HIS BANK -- Former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani of New York City is selling his boutique bank, Giuliani Capital Advisors, in part so he can concentrate on running for president. [A18.] DRUG FAILS IN TRIAL -- The drug Actimmune does not work for patients with a potentially fatal lung condition, idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis, even though its manufacturer had encouraged its use. [C3.] PRICE WAR TAKES TOLL -- Advanced Micro Devices says it is unlikely the company will meet its revenue target for the first quarter, providing evidence that the price war with rival chip maker Intel is taking a toll. [C3.] DUELING CAMPAIGNS -- A bitter battle over lending practices has led to dueling marketing campaigns. Advertising: Stuart Elliott. [C6.] PRODUCT SAFETY INQUIRY -- Two medical device companies and three drug makers have been asked by a House committee chairman for documents as part of an inquiry into product safety and marketing practices. [C6.] NEW EDITOR AT VILLAGE VOICE -- A new editor has been named at The Village Voice, its fifth in little more than a year. [B2.] PATHMARK IS SOLD -- A.& P. is buying Pathmark grocery stores, a move that will create a 550-store, $11 billion supermarket chain. [C2.] CHICKEN, ALWAYS CHICKEN -- There's a good reason for having chicken on the plate at business convention dinners -- it's cheap. But some event planners are switching to smaller meals or snacks to save money. [C8.] CHRYSLER UNIT COULD BE SOLD -- The financing arm of Chrysler Group, the American unit of DaimlerChrysler, could be sold as its parent company considers options. Citigroup wants to buy at least half the shares of Nikko Cordial, in which Citigroup already holds a 4.9 percent stake. [C3.] BREAKUP WOULD BE DIFFICULT -- The chief executive of DaimlerChrysler, Dieter Zetsche, said that it would be difficult to break up Chrysler because of an integrated production system. [C3.] SELLING SHADES -- A campaign for Ray-Ban sunglasses carries a theme -- ''Never hide'' -- that seems counterintuitive for sunglasses. But the idea is to encourage younger consumers to assert their individuality. Advertising: Stuart Elliott. [C2.] RALLY AGAINST AIRBUS JOB CUTS -- Thousands of Airbus employees took to the streets in Toulouse, France, to protest a radical company revamping. [C4.] THE COST OF DELAYS -- The federal government will owe $7 billion in damages because of delays in opening a nuclear waste dump if the repository opens in 2017, the earliest date now possible, the head of the radioactive waste program said. docs.lead_paragraph: Ray Grefe woke up on June 17, 2005, the day before Father's Day and six days before his 55th birthday, with a sharp pain in his shoulder blades. It was 4 in the morning. His wife, Carol Lei, was asleep. So he took a double dose of painkillers -- aspirin plus Tylenol -- and went back to bed. When he woke up again at 7:30 and told Ms. Lei that he was still in pain, she suggested that he skip the family outing to the zoo that morning and go to the nearby St. Mary's Hospital to have his shoulder checked out. They figured he'd pulled a muscle the previous day, probably while rolling around with his 4- and 5-year-old daughters or hitting golf balls at a driving range.

A1 Trip to Ease Tension Opens Rift A pilgrimage to Israel by Roman Catholic bishops from Germany last week, meant to be a symbol of reconciliation between Jews and German Catholics, caused new tension after two bishops compared the plight of Palestinians in the West Bank to that of Jews in the Warsaw Ghetto during World War II. A3 Poverty as a Way of British Life The conditions in a housing project near Manchester, England, epitomize the social deprivation and alienation that is common across Britain. And while Prime Minister Tony Blair has made addressing poverty a priority, his critics say there is little to show after his 10 years in office. A5 Europe Reaches Climate Accord The European Union approved a deal that would make Europe the world's leader in fighting climate change, but would also allow some of Europe's most polluting countries to limit their environmental goals. The allegations were made by a woman who had been in the vehicle. A1 F.B.I. Chief Faces Outrage Bipartisan outrage erupted on Capitol Hill as Robert S. Mueller III, the director of the F.B.I., conceded that his agency had improperly, and sometimes illegally, used the USA Patriot Act to obtain information about people and businesses. A1 5th Student Dies in Bus Crash A fifth college baseball player died of injuries suffered when his team's chartered tour bus plunged 30 feet off a highway overpass last week, bringing the death toll from the accident to seven. A9 Debate Over Image in Textbook After months of lobbying by Sikhs, the California Board of Education voted unanimously to ask the publisher of a seventh-grade history book to remove a portrait of the Sikh founder from future printings. A9 Explosives Missing From Mine Law enforcement officials in Arizona are searching for hundreds of pounds of missing explosives material of the type used in the 1995 bombing of the Alfred P. Murrah Federal Building in Oklahoma City. docs.lead_paragraph: THE National Steinbeck Center, at the top of Main Street in this farming community, exhibits an array of artifacts from John Steinbeck's life and works: family memorabilia, a passport from the 1960s and movie stills from ''The Grapes of Wrath.'' Downstairs, in a climate-controlled vault, is the original manuscript of ''The Pearl,'' his novella published in 1947. There is also an exuberant letter that Steinbeck wrote to a distant relative when he was a teenager, as well as rare footage of him on 16-millimeter film, introducing a 1961 movie, ''Flight.'' Steinbeck aficionados wishing to examine the manuscript of ''The Pearl,'' which he wrote in pencil in small, precise handwriting on a yellow legal pad, have to travel here -- after making an appointment with a part-time archivist, who is in on Mondays, Wednesdays and Fridays.

docs.lead_paragraph: PERUSING the student art on his Web site recently, as he does somewhat obsessively throughout the day, the British collector Charles Saatchi happened upon an entry from a painter named Liu Yang. This artist had posted images of seven of his works, including a painting of a factory set against a haunting gray background and a work on paper depicting a woman's elongated torso. But unlike European, American or Australian users of the site, who use their Web pages there to tell the world everything about themselves -- their favorite artists, what movies and books inspired them, their convictions about art or politics -- Mr. Liu, a student at the Sichuan Fine Arts Institute, simply wrote: ''I can't speak a lot English. Sorry. But love. '' His message trailed off in a few lines of Chinese that read in part: ''I admit that my knowledge of art is limited at present. However, I am sure I can learn quite a bit from your Web site.''

docs.lead_paragraph: Is there anybody out there? Give the question some thought before you answer, because it's more perilous than it seems. Deny the possibility of a universe populated with intelligent extraterrestrials that can speak and mate and battle with humanity, and the science-fiction canon collapses; more than a century's worth of novels, from ''The War of the Worlds'' to ''Old Man's War,'' would find their speculative foundations swept out from underneath them. But admit to a sincere belief in the remotest potential for alien life, and prepare to be fitted for a straitjacket; a recent survey conducted by Baylor University found that more Americans believe in ancient civilizations like the lost continent of Atlantis than in U.F.O.'s. If intelligent humans think the existence of aliens is a perplexing notion, the idea that a small group of astronomers and physicists are attempting to determine if aliens exist is even more so. To the uninitiated and the ignorant (and those of us who fall into both camps), the science of SETI, the Search for Extraterrestrial Intelligence, is as inscrutable as the phenomenon it seeks, conjuring up images of mad scientists out of old EC comic books, their ears trained to intricate listening devices as they scan the interstellar static for unearthly broadcasts -- or worse, of hapless crackpots chasing down every report of alien abduction they read in Weekly World News.

headline.main: Trying to Meet the Neighbors
