docs.lead_paragraph: TELECOM DEAL IN ITALY -- Telefónica and a group of Italian investors have agreed to pay about $5.6 billion for an 18 percent stake in Telecom Italia, which would let Telefónica, Europe's second-largest telecommunications provider, enter the Italian market and extend its presence in Latin America. [Page C1.] ALL ME, ALL THE TIME -- The social networking phenomenon is leaving the confines of the personal computer. Powerful new mobile devices are allowing people to send round-the-clock updates about their vacations, their moods or their latest haircut. [C1.] A NEW FILM RISK -- If the horror at Virginia Tech has changed the chemistry of America's popular culture, those who count box-office receipts at Lionsgate will be among the first to know. The independent studio still plans to release on June 8 its ''Hostel: Part II,'' about the torture killing of college students. [C1.] SPEAKING VIAGRA -- In promoting Viagra, its impotence treatment, Pfizer has irritated regulators with its wink-and-a-nod ads. Now it has ads feature middle-aged men and women talking in a made-up language, save for one word. [C1.] YAHOO MAKES A DEAL -- Yahoo plans to acquire Right Media, a privately held company that runs an advertising marketplace. [C2.] U.N.'S SOLE ACCREDITED BLOGGER -- Matthew Lee, left, is the only blogger at the United Nations with media credentials, entitling him to free office space and access to briefings and news conferences. The United Nations is one of the few institutions of size and importance that allow bloggers not affiliated with larger, more traditional media companies. [C6.] THE FIVE-MINUTE 'STARSKY' -- The Sony Corporation has shrunk episodes of '70s and '80s television series to three and a half to five minutes, hoping to create a new business in retooling old shows for a new era of entertainment. [C4.] COMPETITIVE VOCABULARY -- Now that spelling bees have been turned into a hit Broadway show and crossword puzzles into a movie, the publishers of the American Heritage dictionary are hoping to create a cultural moment with a competitive game about word definitions. [C4.] ALL YOUR STUFF, ONLINE -- At least three companies have emerged in recent months with the aim of helping people catalog and value their possessions and post them online. The plan is to attract millions of people, then find retailers who want to sell them more items to go along with their possessions. [C8.] MORE GARDEN THAN GUN -- The title of Garden & Gun, a new lifestyle magazine from Charleston, S.C., might not have raised eyebrows had it not been for the fact that the premiere issue hit newsstands just days before the shootings at Virginia Tech on April 16. [C6.] GOOGLING STATE DATA -- Four states have joined forces with Google to make information from their Web sites more directly accessible through Internet searches. [C8.] INVESTING IN CLEAN ENERGY -- Money flowing into alternative energy companies is raising the threat of a bubble, according to a research firm, but investors may be overlooking other clean technologies. [C7.] A PLUG FOR PHONE LEAKS -- Drumming up business would seem to be an easy task for those who sell encrypted cellphones in Italy. All they have to do is browse the major newspapers, looking for leaked telephone conversations. [C6.] EX-ABC NEWSMAN MOVING TO TIME -- Mark Halperin, the longtime political director of ABC News and a pioneer of online reporting, is moving to Time magazine. [C2.] ADS FOR INTERNET RADIO -- A start-up company, TargetSpot, is trying to turn the nascent field of Internet radio into a viable business, and CBS Radio is its first customer. [C10.] CHINA TIGHTENS MONEY AGAIN -- For the second time this month, China has ordered banks to hold more of their deposits in reserve as it seeks to prevent credit and investment growth from destabilizing the economy. [C2.] BEST PLACES TO BLOG ABOUT -- Clinton Hill in Brooklyn is the most blogged-about neighborhood in America, says a Web site that found a link between gentrification and the number of people who feel compelled to think out loud about the changes in their backyards. [C6.] WHAT GOES AROUND -- The pop culture magazine Radar has accused a Chilean magazine of ripping off its story on ''Toxic Bachelors,'' but freely admits that it borrowed the concept from other sources, like a book by Danielle Steele and the ''Sex and the City'' series. [C6.]

docs.lead_paragraph: MAJOR PATENT RULING -- The Supreme Court, in its most significant patent ruling in years, made it more difficult to get a patent on new products that combine elements of existing inventions. [Page C1.] SAFEGUARDING FOOD -- As Food and Drug Administration inspectors head to China to investigate contaminated pet food, critics in Washington are warning that the agency is wholly understaffed and underfunded to safeguard America's food supply. [C1.] DELTA EXITS BANKRUPTCY -- Delta Air Lines has emerged from bankruptcy protection after cutting billions in costs during a 19-month reorganization. Its board must now find a new chief executive to replace Gerald Grinstein, above, and decide whether to sell or spin off Comair, its regional feeder carrier. [C6.] LURE OF LASALLE -- For Bank of America and the Royal Bank of Scotland, acquiring LaSalle Bank of Chicago would offer each an efficient way to gain a strong foothold there and throughout the Midwest, where LaSalle has 140 branches. [C1.] QUESTIONABLE TECHNIQUE -- An accounting technique called gain on sale is haunting New Century Financial, a subprime mortgage lender now facing bankruptcy and investigations by federal prosecutors and securities regulators. [C1.] PROMISE OF PLANKTON -- Some Silicon Valley technocrats are betting plankton can save the planet. Several groups are working on ventures to grow vast floating fields of plankton that could absorb carbon dioxide from the atmosphere and carry it to the depths of the ocean. [C1.] WOLFOWITZ DEFENDS HIMSELF -- Paul D. Wolfowitz, the president of the World Bank, told bank directors it would be unfair and hypocritical to dismiss him, but he hinted he might be willing to resign if he was cleared of any misconduct. [A3.] HALLIBURTON DENIES BREAKING LAW -- A Halliburton executive insisted during a Senate hearing concerning the company's business dealings in Iran that it had done nothing wrong. [A6.] DEBATE OVER CHANGES FOR F.D.A. -- he Senate debated legislation that could fundamentally change the way the F.D.A. operates by providing it with more power and more money to insure that drugs are as safe as advertised. [A18.] AN ENERGY CHALLENGE -- With the increasing use of coal inevitable, clearing a hurdle to burn it on a big scale -- separating the carbon dioxide and sequestering it -- could turn out to be one of the major engineering challenges of the century. [Science, F3.] CHINESE WEB COMPANY TO GO PUBLIC -- China's leading e-commerce company, Alibaba.com, is planning to go public later this year in what could be the biggest initial public offering there for an Internet company. [C10.] GROUP CRITICIZES WAL-MART -- Human Rights Watch contends that Wal-Mart's efforts to keep out labor unions have often violated federal law and infringed on workers' rights. Wal-Mart, with more than 1.3 million workers at nearly 4,000 stores in the United States, strongly defended its practices. [C3.] UPDATING 'OL' LONELY' -- The Maytag repairman, who started appearing in national commercials in 1967, is becoming more active and gregarious in a change meant to update the concept of ''Ol' Lonely'' for a new generation of shoppers. [C3.] GOOGLE RESPONDS TO VIACOM SUIT -- In an initial response to the lawsuit filed in United States District Court in Manhattan, Google says Viacom's $1 billion copyright infringement suit over video clips on YouTube is unfounded and ought to be dismissed. [C2.] PROFIT DECLINES AT VERIZON -- Verizon's profit declined in the first quarter, but the company continued to have strong growth in wireless and broadband subscriptions as it begins to offer Internet and television services. [C2.] GOOD NEWS FOR TWO TABLOIDS -- With the exception of two New York tabloids that showed solid gains -- The New York Post and The Daily News -- newspaper circulation continued a sharp decline nationally, new figures show. [C10.] KELLOGG'S EARNINGS RISE -- Kellogg's first-quarter earnings climbed 17 percent, helped by stronger snack sales and a tax benefit. The company, which makes food like cereal, cookies and waffles, also raised its full-year outlook. Kellogg's North American sales rose 7 percent as revenue rose 9 percent. Excluding the tax benefit, earnings were 70 cents a share. [C11.] DEUTSCHE BÖRSE BUYS EXCHANGE -- The German stock exchange operator Deutsche Börse has agreed to buy International Securities Exchange Holdings, an options exchange in New York that is the largest after the Chicago Board Options Exchange, for $2.8 billion. [C10.] WHEN THE BACKUP FAILS -- When the editorial computer system crashed at Business 2.0, a Time Inc. magazine that has written about the importance of backing up computer files, its back-up server failed to do its job. Luckily, the monthly magazine has been able to recover. [C11.] LESSONS FOR HEDGE FUNDS -- Hedge and equity funds are discovering the they may need to develop a credible public persona to capitalize on the keen interest in their high-returning funds and to go public. [C10.] WHEN TRAVELING, TAKE FOOD -- Dieticians and nutritionists recommend taking along a stash of food, which can help relieve stress if you should get stuck on the tarmac. [C5.]

docs.lead_paragraph: Belgian French-language newspapers were back on Google after agreeing that the search engine can link to their Web sites, the first signs of a thaw in a copyright dispute. But neither has so far settled a major part of the dispute: the use of newspaper article links on Google News. In February, Google lost a lawsuit filed by the newspapers, forcing it to remove headlines and links to news articles posted on its Google News service and stored in its search engine's cache without the copyright owners' permission. In a joint statement, Google and the newspapers' copyright group Copiepresse said they had decided that Google could once again list the newspapers on the search engine.

docs.abstract: Sophisticated Internet users have banded together to publish and widely distribute secret code used by technology and movie industries to prevent piracy of high-definition movies; distribution of code may not pose serious threat to studios, because it requires technical expertise and specialized software to use, but its relentless spread is seen as lesson in mob power on Internet and futility of censorship in digital world; uproar came in response to cease-and-desist letters from lawyers demanding that code be removed from several Web sites; legal notices instead sparked proliferation of code on Web sites, chat rooms and user-submitted news sites like Digg.com; Digg initially removed codes, but users protested and Digg decided to keep postings containing code; some say there is no realistic way to pursue legal remedy against thousands of Internet users; photo of Digg.com founder Kevin Rose (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Q:I have a split life -- doing a few kinds of work that might not make sense to everyone. What is the best way to handle multiple lives that do not necessarily relate to one another? A: People with incongruous occupations tend to be cautious about revealing the different aspects of their working lives. And rightly so. Just as certain topics are off-limits on a first date -- say, your habit of phoning your mother three times a day or your inability to sleep with the lights off -- showing a bit too much of your working life too soon may cause some people to give up on you before they recognize your talents.

docs.lead_paragraph: DIGITAL cameras are amazing. Even compact digital cameras selling for less than $100 take photographs with great resolution. The point-and-shoot cameras are great, that is, as long as the subject of the photo is not moving very fast. But if the photographer is trying to catch the moment that the little soccer player kicks in his first goal or when the black Labrador leaps in the air to snag the Frisbee, then he may find a picture of an empty field or a blue sky. The compact digital camera can take so long to react after you snap the shutter release button that the moment has passed and the desired image is never captured.

headline.main: Seizing the Moment

docs.lead_paragraph: ALABAMA WINS STEEL MILL -- ThyssenKrupp, the German steel maker, chose a site in Alabama for a $4.2 billion steel plant that will bring 2,700 new jobs to the state. The company will build the mill, scheduled to open in 2010, in Mount Vernon. The site was chosen because of its ''cost efficiency'' and ''site specific capital expenditures,'' ThyssenKrupp said. The company picked Alabama over Louisiana, which spent $3 million over 15 months trying to lure the plant, but could not compete with the financial incentives offered by Alabama, said Michael Olivier, Louisiana's secretary for economic development. Alabama allocated $900 million of tax-exempt debt authorized by Congress after Hurricane Katrina to help economies in areas hit by the storm, and another $400 million of bonds to help with infrastructure costs. The state also approved 20-year breaks on state and local property taxes and a 30-year period in which to apply tax credits on the plant's income to recover capital costs. (BLOOMBERG NEWS) HOME BUILDER SELLS UNIT -- The home builder KB Home said an unidentified bidder offered $783.2 million, or $71.85 a share, for its stake in a French subsidiary, Kaufman & Broad. KB Home, which is based in Los Angeles, owns 10.9 million shares in the subsidiary, which accounted for $378.4 million, or 21.4 percent, of KB Home's first-quarter revenue. KB Home said it was evaluating the offer. It is also looking at other strategic alternatives, including a public or private offering of its shares in the division or keeping the stake, equal to 49 percent of voting securities in Kaufman. EX-CHIEF OF HBO PLEADS -- The former chief executive of HBO, Chris Albrecht, settled a criminal domestic violence charge in Las Vegas, when his lawyer pleaded no contest on his behalf to battery and agreed to pay a $1,000 fine, authorities said. Mr. Albrecht, left, lost his job after he was arrested early Sunday outside the MGM Grand Hotel, where police reported seeing him ''grabbing a white female by the throat with both hands.'' Mr. Albrecht's girlfriend, Karla Jensen, declined medical treatment and told police she did not want to press charges. Mr. Albrecht, 54, and Ms. Jensen, 37, issued statements through a publicist in New York saying both were to blame for what Ms. Jensen characterized as a mistake. They said they intended to remain together. PROFIT IS DOWN AT FORTIS -- Fortis, a Belgian-Dutch bank and insurance company that is part of a consortium trying to buy ABN Amro, said its first-quarter profit fell 12 percent on a decline in its banking division. Fortis reported earnings of 1.17 billion euros ($1.58 billion), down from 1.33 billion euros a year earlier. It said profit at its banking arm fell 13 percent, to 903 million euros ($1.22 billion), largely from a one-time gain of 120 million euros in the first quarter of 2006 after reassessing the value of an investment. Insurance profit rose 4 percent, to 352 million euros ($477 million), reflecting strong gains in Fortis's life insurance business, which offset 86 million euros ($117 million) in damage claims after a major storm hit northern Europe in January. Fortis shares fell 1.7 percent, to 32.73 euros ($44.26), in Amsterdam. The bank and its partners in the consortium are trying to outbid a friendly offer for ABN Amro from Barclays. TOTAL TO SELL STAKE -- Total plans to sell its 13 percent stake in the pharmaceutical company Sanofi-Aventis, the French oil company's chief executive told shareholders. Total is one of Sanofi-Aventis' largest shareholders, with a stake worth 12 billion euros ($16.18 billion). Christophe de Margerie, Total's chief executive, said it would sell its stake ''probably in the short term.'' He made the comment at Total's annual shareholders meeting in Paris. Speculation of a sale of the Total stake has swirled for weeks. Sanofi-Aventis earnings for the first quarter fell 17 percent, suffering from lingering integration costs arising from the 2004 merger between Sanofi-Synthelabo and Aventis. NOKIA'S BIGGEST ORDER -- Nokia, the world's biggest mobile phone maker, unveiled the largest order in its history, to supply handsets in China in a deal worth $2.5 billion. The order from China Postel, China's largest mobile phone wholesaler, could represent more than 20 million phones, analysts said. Nokia, which sells more than a third of all mobile phones across the world, has a strong position in emerging markets like China, thanks in part to its efficient distribution system. Nokia's lead on the global market over its closest rival, Motorola, grew to its widest in years in the beginning of 2007 as the Finnish company benefits from its early entry into fast-growing emerging markets. And with Motorola's decision at the start of 2007 to back away from the tightest competition in the low-end segment, Nokia has few rivals there. (REUTERS) TRIAL ON GOOGLE AD SYSTEM -- A federal judge ordered Google to face a jury trial in a trademark infringement suit that aims at the workings of the company's main source of revenue. In the lawsuit, American Blind and Wallpaper Factory charges that Google abuses trademarks by allowing rivals of a company to buy ads that appear when consumers search for information on that company. David Rammelt, the lead lawyer for American Blinds, said Federal District Judge Jeremy Fogel of the Northern District of California had set Nov. 9 for jury selection. AdWords is the popular online system which serves up ads tied to searches users perform on Google or Google-affiliated sites. The program accounted for 98 percent or more of the company's $10.6 billion in revenue last year. (REUTERS) PROVIDENCE EQUITY BUYS USIS -- Providence Equity Partners, a buyout firm focused on media and communications, has agreed to acquire USIS, an employee-screening company, from two other investment firms for $1.5 billion, USIS said in a statement. The sellers are Welsh Carson Anderson & Stowe and the Carlyle Group, USIS said. The two firms bought USIS in 2003 in a transaction valued at $717 million. Lehman Brothers is the financial adviser for USIS, based in Falls Church, Va., and is providing financing for the acquisition, which is expected to close in the third quarter. Providence Equity, based in Providence, R.I., manages about $21 billion in equity funds. (BLOOMBERG NEWS)

docs.lead_paragraph: OXYCONTIN MAKER PLEADS GUILTY -- The company that makes the painkiller OxyContin and three of its current and former executives pleaded guilty to charges that the firm misled doctors and patients when it claimed that the drug was less likely to be abused than traditional narcotics. [Page A1.] ACCORD ON TRADE PACTS -- The Bush administration reached a major accord with the House speaker, Nancy Pelosi, and other Democrats to attach environmental and worker protections in several pending trade agreements, clearing the way for early passage of some pacts. [A1.] A JETBLUE DEPARTURE -- JetBlue's service meltdown during a mid-February storm has now led its founder, David Neeleman, to heed the urgings of his board and reluctantly agree to step aside as chief executive of the airline. [C1.] SMOKING JOINS SEX AND VIOLENCE -- The Motion Picture Association of America said portrayals of smoking would be considered alongside sex and violence in assessing the suitability of movies for young viewers. Films that appear to glamorize smoking will risk a more restrictive rating. [C1.] CONFLICTS AMONG PAY CONSULTANTS -- Congressional lawmakers are looking into the potential conflicts among executive compensation consulting firms that do other lucrative work for the companies whose pay they help devise. [C1.] UNHAPPY WITH FORD'S EX-CHIEF -- A group of Ford Motor shareholders at the annual meeting took turns criticizing every decision made by William Clay Ford Jr. as the former chief executive, except one -- his decision to hire Alan R. Mulally as his successor. Mr. Mulally urged patience, and promised results ''in the months and the years ahead.'' [C3.] RETAIL SALES SAG -- From department stores to discount chains, sales were dismal last month, suggesting that rising gas prices and the flagging housing market are starting to weigh on American consumers. [C1.] A NUCLEAR PLANT REBORN -- The Tennessee Valley Authority plans to reopen a nuclear reactor that was closed 22 years ago for safety reasons. The move, after $1.8 billion in repairs, reflects increased interest in nuclear power, and underscores how hard companies think it will be to build a new plant. [C3.] CROSS-EXAMINATION CONTINUES -- F. David Radler, the chief witness against the media baron Conrad M. Black, endured more withering cross-examination and was again called a liar before a federal jury hearing the case against Mr. Black and others accused of stealing millions from the publishing company Hollinger International. [C5.] GOOGLE'S FOCUS -- The chief executive at Google, Eric E. Schmidt, speaking to shareholders, said the company's long and varied array of initiatives was organized around three ideas: ''search, ads and apps,'' using a shorthand for applications, or software programs. [C5.] TREASURY INQUIRY ON FILMMAKER -- The filmmaker Michael Moore, below, is being investigated by the Treasury Department over a trip he made to Cuba for his new film, ''Sicko.'' At issue is whether he violated restrictions on travel to Cuba when he accompanied sick workers seeking free medical care. On Mr. Moore's Web site, the film's producer, Meghan O'Hara, called the department's actions a ''politically motivated investigation.'' [A24.] A FALL LINEUP TAKES SHAPE -- NBC took the first steps toward rebuilding its prime-time schedule by ordering five new hours of drama programs, which will be part of the fall schedule the network plans to announce to advertisers on Monday. [C2.] EUROPEAN BANK SIGNALS RATE RISE -- The European Central Bank signaled that it would lift interest rates as early as June to prevent a robust European economy from stoking inflation. [C7.] BOOST FOR INTERNET TV VENTURE -- Joost, a start-up that delivers television programming over the Internet, said that it had received $45 million in financing from venture capitalists and content partners including CBS and Viacom. [C7.] DOW SLUMPS NEARLY 150 POINTS -- Stocks plunged, slicing nearly 150 points off the Dow Jones industrial average after reports of weak sales at many of the major retailers. [C9.] ONLINE Business Briefing Articles on these developments are at nytimes.com/business. The former top lawyer at the software maker Comverse Technology Inc. was sentenced yesterday to a year and one day in prison for his role in a stock options backdating scheme, becoming the first corporate executive to be sentenced for options-related crimes. (REUTERS) Sara Lee Corporation, the food and household products maker, said that its third-quarter profit nearly tripled on revenue growth in its international beverage, bakery, household and body care segments. (AP) The Goldman Sachs Group said that John Browne, who quit as chief executive of BP on May 1, had resigned from the Goldman board. (REUTERS) EchoStar Communications, parent of the Dish Network satellite television service, said that its quarterly profit rose 7 percent as subscriber growth helped overcome higher marketing costs. (REUTERS) The American International Group, one of the world's largest insurers, said that its profit rose more than 29 percent in the first quarter on strong growth in underwriting results and investment income. (AP) The Interpublic Group of Companies posted a larger-than-expected quarterly loss yesterday as it struggled with high salary costs and weak revenue in Europe and Asia. (REUTERS) TyCo International was named in a bondholders' lawsuit filed by the American International Group, which is trying to stop Tyco's planned bond tender offer, saying the company was offering a below-contract price for its debt. (REUTERS)

The medium is of course broadcast television, which remains a powerful way to peddle products despite the recent inroads made by alternative ways to watch programs, which include the Internet, digital video recorders, cellphones, DVD players and video on demand.

docs.lead_paragraph: IN Rupert Murdoch's world, two things are certain: the sun never sets on the kingdom, and a TV is always on in the background. On the evening of April 26, several large television monitors adorned the terrace of Mr. Murdoch's Beverly Hills mansion for a dinner celebrating a special edition of ''American Idol'' that raised more than $70 million to fight poverty. An Asian noodle station was set out by the pool; nearby, sushi chefs busily sliced tuna for ''Idol'' co-hosts Simon Cowell and Ryan Seacrest, and seven, hyperactive ''Idol'' finalists who, when they weren't clamoring around megastar Tom Cruise, dreamily watched themselves on the big screens. Wendi Deng, Mr. Murdoch's wife, wore a billowy, green dress and introduced their 5-year-old daughter, Grace, to guests before sending her to bed.

headline.main: Tilting At a Digital Future

docs.snippet: As is so often the case with Rupert Murdoch, his bid for Dow Jones is counterintuitive and seemingly quixotic.

docs.lead_paragraph: Jonathan Coulton sat in Gorilla Coffee in Brooklyn, his Apple PowerBook open before him, and began slogging through the day's e-mail. Coulton is 36 and shaggily handsome. In September 2005, he quit his job as a computer programmer and, with his wife's guarded blessing, became a full-time singer and songwriter. He set a quixotic goal for himself: for the next year, he would write and record a song each week, posting each one to his blog. ''It was a sort of forced-march approach to creativity,'' he admitted to me over the sound of the cafe's cappuccino frothers. He'd always wanted to be a full-time musician, and he figured the only way to prove to himself he could do it was with a drastic challenge. ''I learned that it is possible to squeeze a song out of just about anything,'' he said. ''But it's not always an easy or pleasant process.'' Given the self-imposed time constraints, the ''Thing a Week'' songs are remarkably good. Coulton tends toward geeky, witty pop tunes: one song, ''Tom Cruise Crazy,'' is a sympathetic ode to the fame-addled star, while ''Code Monkey'' is a rocking anthem about dead-end programming jobs. By the middle of last year, his project had attracted a sizable audience. More than 3,000 people, on average, were visiting his site every day, and his most popular songs were being downloaded as many as 500,000 times; he was making what he described as ''a reasonable middle-class living'' -- between $3,000 and $5,000 a month -- by selling CDs and digital downloads of his work on iTunes and on his own site.

headline.main: -Sex, Drugs And Updating Your Blog-

docs.abstract: Clive Thompson article on singer and songwriter Jonathan Coulton, who has set goal of writing song every week and posting it to his blog; he has close, even symbiotic, relationship with his fans, who promote his work worldwide through YouTube music videos they have created and other online tools; he maintains online relationship with fans, responding to enormous amounts of e-mail; Coulton is emblematic of today's performing artists, particularly new or struggling musicians, who are eager to master social rules of Internet fame; photo (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: THE Internet search engine is an indispensable tool of modern life and an advertising gold mine for Google, the favorite first stop on the Web. But searching accounts for only about 5 percent of the time people spend online; the other 95 percent is spent on the wider Web, where a different advertising landscape looms. Instead of the short text ads that appear on a Google results page after a search, visitors often find display ads that are the Internet's equivalents of glossy magazine ads or television commercials. These are typically the province of brand advertisers like Cadillac and Coke.

docs.lead_paragraph: Google said on Wednesday that it was changing its approach to Internet searches by combining results from its established Web search service with offerings that help users find videos, images, maps and other content. The new service, which Google is calling universal search, was introduced on Wednesday and will gradually become evident to users. It underscores the continual efforts by major search engines like Google, Yahoo, Microsoft and Ask.com to spruce up their offerings to draw users to their services.

docs.lead_paragraph: Pros and Cons Of Web-Based Mail Q. I have always used Web-based mail accounts that let me do everything online from anywhere. I know there are advantages with Outlook and other programs, but is it really worth the hassle of managing mail on the local machine? A. Maximum mailbox size used to be a major factor when choosing between a Web-based mail service and a program that downloads your messages to your hard drive from your Internet provider's servers. This is not as much of an issue now, with services like Gmail from Google, Yahoo Mail and Windows Live Hotmail now offering at least two gigabytes of mail storage.

docs.lead_paragraph: Amazon.com, the biggest online seller of CDs, is joining the movement against copy-protection software for digital music. It plans to sell songs that can be freely copied to any computer, cellphone or music player, including the iPod from Apple. The move could be another step toward the demise of the copy-protection systems that have frustrated some online music buyers and created confusion about compatibility between digital players and downloaded songs. Critics charge that the software has slowed the public embrace of legal digital downloads while failing to stop illicit copying, at a time when the music industry is desperate for ways to make up for declining CD sales.

headline.main: Amazon to Sell Music Without Copy Protection

[Page C1.] TAINTED TOOTHPASTE -- Chinese authorities are investigating two companies after toothpaste exported to Latin America was found to be tainted with diethylene glycol, an industrial solvent and prime ingredient in some antifreeze fluid. [C1.] PAY ATTENTION, PLEASE -- Viacom, the media conglomerate that owns cable networks like MTV and Comedy Central, says it has devised new formats to try to keep its young viewers glued to the television set when the commercials are appearing. ''They're younger, they're more quickly engaged and more quickly dismissive if they're not engaged,'' said Judy McGrath, above, chairman and chief executive of MTV Networks. [C6.] BIG-BOY LETTERS ARE CHALLENGED -- Correspondence among investors known as big-boy letters are widely used and represent a private contract among presumably sophisticated investors. Now they face a legal challenge. [C1.] WHAT'S KERKORIAN UP TO? -- The latest Securities and Exchange Commission filing by the Tracinda Corporation, the billionaire financier Kirk Kerkorian's holding company, has analysts wondering if this is the opening move in a plan to take the MGM company private. [C1.] TRADE ISSUES WITH CHINA -- As the senior trade officials for United States and China begin talks, some question whether the Bush administration's efforts to open China to American goods can satisfy a Congress irate over a trade deficit with China that rose to $232 billion last year. [C1.] IDEA FROM GOOGLE: AN AUCTION -- Google has proposed that the Federal Communications Commission allocate radio spectrum employing the same kind of auction that the search engine company now uses in selling advertisements to create more competition among cable companies and Internet service providers. [C10.] MYSPACE EXPOSES SEX OFFENDERS -- MySpace, the popular social networking site, has agreed to provide authorities in all 50 states with the names, addresses and online profiles of thousands of known convicted sexual offenders who have opened up accounts on its service. [C8.] LOWE'S PROFIT MISSES MARK -- The Lowe's Company, the No. 2 home improvement chain behind Home Depot, reported a lower-than-expected first-quarter profit and has cut its full-year earnings outlook. [C7.] COURT TO HEAR BOND CASE -- The Supreme Court has agreed to rule on important tax issues involving interest and taxes on municipal bonds in a case with the potential to change the market for such bonds. [C3.] MOVIE MAY ENLIVEN DEBATE -- Insurance industry officials and health policy experts suggest that Michael Moore's movie on the American health care system is likely to provoke debate, not radical change. [C3.] EMI GROUP SALE WINS SUPPORT -- The board at the music giant EMI Group has decided to support a new $4.7 billion offer from a private British investor, Terra Firma Capital Partners. [C3.] JUST LOOKING FOR A RETURN -- The Chinese government's $3 billion purchase of a nonvoting stake in the Blackstone Group was simply a way to raise returns on overseas investments, a Chinese official says. [C4.] CLINTON BOOKS DUE EARLIER -- The publishers of two rival biographies of Hillary Rodham Clinton have moved up their on-sale dates once again to the first week in June in a game of publishing one-upmanship. [C3.] RETRIAL FOR BROKERS -- The United States attorney's office in Brooklyn said it would retry former brokers for Citigroup, Merrill Lynch and Lehman Brothers on charges that they conspired to commit fraud by allowing day traders to eavesdrop on orders made through internal squawk boxes. [C11.] TAX GETS SCRUTINY -- A tax originally intended to ensure that rich investors did not live tax-free is not working as planned, the Joint Committee on Taxation says. But a nonpartisan tax group has a solution. [C2.] SAUDIS BUY G.E. PLASTICS UNIT -- General Electric agreed yesterday to sell its plastics division for $11.6 billion to the largest public company in Saudi Arabia, the Saudi Basic Industries Corporation known as Sabic. Jeffrey R. Immelt, the chief executive of G.E., said the deal would transform the industry by combining Sabic's low-cost materials and global reach with G.E.'s strong marketing and technology. [C8.] YOU'RE FIRED -- A new study examining turnover among top executives has found that corporate boards were more than three times as likely to dismiss failing chief executives as they were a decade ago. [C6.] LUGGAGE-FREE TRAVEL -- Some executives are shipping their bags ahead when they travel on business -- picking luggage up at their hotel, not an airport. And more businesses are providing these services. [C9.] ONLINE RETIREMENT -- As life spans lengthen, experts on aging say it is more important than ever to prepare for the physical and psychological aspects of retirement. A special section is at nytimes.com/retirement. BUSINESS OF GREEN -- The International Herald Tribune provides a global dialogue on the environment at nytimes.com/blogs. If the original Palm Treo was like the curvaceous Jayne Mansfield, the 755p, with service from Sprint, is more Kirsten Dunst. The five-ounce 755p is less than an inch thick and has a 320-pixel-square color touch screen and a 1.3-megapixel camera. The device is compatible with Sprint's EV-DO network, which means it can download data at near-broadband speeds.

docs.lead_paragraph: HIGH GAS PRICES COULD LAST -- Gasoline prices are spiking again -- to an average of $3.22 a gallon and close to $4 a gallon in many areas -- and some oil executives warn that current fuel shortages could become a long-term problem, leading to stubbornly higher prices at the pump. [Page A1.] 9/11 INSURANCE SETTLEMENT -- Gov. Eliot Spitzer's administration announced the settlement of all insurance claims at ground zero, making $4.55 billion available for rebuilding the World Trade Center site and bringing an end to a protracted legal battle over payouts related to the 9/11 terrorist attack. [A1.] GREENSPAN SPEAKS; DOW FALLS -- The Dow Jones industrial average passed 13,600 for the first time, but shares plummeted to close at 13,525 after Alan Greenspan, the former Fed chairman, expressed concern that China's stock market, which has recently been hitting record highs, might be in for a sharp decline. [C11.] TRADE AGREEMENT WITH CHINA -- Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr. announced a limited agreement to open markets in China and develop clean coal-burning technologies. [C1.] EARLIER CONCERN ON DIABETES DRUG -- A leading diabetes doctor sent the Food and Drug Administration a letter warning of the heart risks of the drug Avandia seven years ago, and the following year the F.D.A. reprimanded GlaxoSmithKline. [C1.] JAPANESE ENGINEERS GO ABROAD -- As Japan's once-vaunted electronics industry downsizes to survive global competition, thousands of Japanese engineers and other industry professionals are going to Taiwan, South Korea and China to work at fast-growing companies that want to use Japanese technological expertise. [C1.] TARGET'S PROFIT UP 18% -- Target, the No. 2 discount chain behind Wal-Mart, said its quarterly profit rose almost 18 percent, to $651 million, or 75 cents a share, from $554 million a year earlier. The women's apparel retailer Talbots posted a better-than-expected profit. [C11.] NO CRIMINAL CHARGES FOR LAW FIRM -- Federal prosecutors said they would not file criminal charges against Sidley Austin, one of the nation's largest law firms, over its work with questionable tax shelters that helped wealthy investors evade billions of dollars in taxes. [C1.] LOTT SUPPORTS IMMIGRATION BILL -- Trent Lott, the Senate minority whip and a conservative pro-business Republican, made an all-out pitch for a comprehensive immigration bill as the Senate voted to cut the size of a proposed guest worker program, infuriating employers. [A24.] E-MAIL TO ORDINARY CELLPHONES -- You no longer need a Treo or BlackBerry to get e-mail on the move. Three new services -- from Google, Yahoo and Teleflip -- can deliver mail directly to ordinary nonsmart cellphones, free of charge, but there are compromises. State of the Art: David Pogue. [C1.] SAFETY COMMISSION NOMINEE QUITS -- Michael E. Baroody, a senior lobbyist for the National Association of Manufacturers, withdrew his nomination to head the Consumer Product Safety Commission as a growing number of senators questioned both his suitability and a $150,000 departure payment that the association was preparing to give him. [A18.] 'HI' TIMES ON MADISON AVENUE -- The latest buzzword on Madison Avenue seems to be ''hello.'' Companies as diverse as Apple, Avon, the Lincoln Financial Group and Level, a vodka brand, are using the salutation in a consumer-friendly advertising approach. Advertising: Stuart Elliott. [C4.] ADVANCE GAS PRICE WARNING -- A Michigan-based gas station chain is offering to send text messages to customers, giving them at least two hours' notice of impending price increases. [A22.] RISING RUPEE WORRIES INDIANS -- Concerned that the rising value of the Indian rupee may limit the country's economic growth, especially in the lucrative outsourcing industry, monetary policy experts have started putting pressure on the Reserve Bank of India to stem the rupee's rise. [C4.] MINING COMPANY RAISES BID -- The Russian mining company Norilsk Nickel raised its bid for LionOre Mining International of Canada to $6.27 billion, showing its determination to win a bidding war with a rival, Xstrata. [C5.] TWO-WAY G.P.S. IS HERE -- A new two-way radio from Garmin not only tells you where you are, but it maps your location for others. Circuits. [C8.] ONLINE BUSINESS OF GREEN -- The International Herald Tribune provides a global dialogue on the environment at nytimes.com/business. BUSINESS TRAVEL -- With more in-flight food and entertainment options, airlines are giving their business customers the C.E.O treatment. A special section is at nytimes.com/business. Business Briefing Articles on these developments are at nytimes.com/business. MEMBERS OF CONGRESS complained to the United States trade representative that the complete text of a free-trade deal with South Korea has not been made public, even though a required 90-day Congressional review period is more than half over. (REUTERS)

docs.lead_paragraph: A former top Justice Department aide testified on Wednesday that she had ''crossed the line'' in considering the political beliefs of applicants for nonpartisan legal jobs and suggested that earlier testimony by Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales and another top official about the dismissals of federal prosecutors may have been flawed. Monica M. Goodling, the former Justice official, told a House panel that she regretted favoring applicants with Republican credentials for lower level prosecutor jobs or prestigious postings at Justice headquarters, actions that could violate federal employment laws.

headline.main: Ex-Justice Aide Admits Politics Affected Hiring

docs.abstract: Former top Justice Dept aide Monica M Goodling testifies under grant of immunity that she 'crossed the line' in considering political beliefs of applicants for nonpartisan legal jobs and appears to contradict earlier testimony by Atty Gen Alberto Gonzales and other top officials about dismissals of federal prosecutors; Gonzales testified that he had not spoken to senior aides since firings to 'protect the integrity of this investigation,' but Goodling relates conversation she had with Gonzales about that matter just before she resigned; she claims she did not play significant role in dismissals and says she never discussed them with Karl Rove or Harriet E Miers; accuses Paul J McNulty, outgoing deputy attorney general, of misleading Congress; holds that he knew more details about White House involvement in firings than he acknowledged in his Feb 6 testimony to Senate panel; Goodling acknowledges repeatedly that she had improperly sought to gauge political leanings of applicants when she reviewed resumes for nonpartisan jobs or promotions, including posts as assistant US attorneys and immigration judges; photos (M)
docs.snippet: Monica M. Goodling said she had “crossed the line” in considering the political beliefs of job applicants.

Now, however, my Volvo was zipping over what was once the world's longest suspension bridge, heading west, and nothing could stop me. Nothing, that is, but the police officers at the toll plaza.

docs.lead_paragraph: Google has been warned that it may be violating European Union privacy laws by storing search data from its users for up to two years, the latest example of a United States technology giant whose practices face a collision with European standards. An advisory panel of data-protection chiefs from the 27 countries in the European Union sent a letter last week to Google asking it to justify its policy of retaining data on Internet addresses and individual search habits, Friso Roscam Abbing, a spokesman for the European Union's justice commissioner, Franco Frattini, said on Friday.

byline.original: By KEVIN J. O'BRIEN and THOMAS CRAMPTON

docs.lead_paragraph: IT takes all kinds of investors to make a market, or so it seemed at a conference this week of the crème de la crème of money managers. Typically a reclusive bunch, the managers agreed to offer up a few of their investment ideas to a roomful of attentive money managers in an effort to raise money for pediatric cancer and other childhood diseases. With hedge funds complaining that it has never been harder to make money, the crowd of nearly 1,000 sat glued to their seats, with papers rustling and BlackBerrys clicking as soon as a name of a stock was mentioned. The ideas included Google, coal, real estate investment trusts, and the bond insurers exposed to subprime debt.

docs.lead_paragraph: On a spring Saturday, about 90 students from Stanford and as many from the University of California, Berkeley, converged on Google's corporate campus for a day of spirited team competition over mind-bending puzzles, Lego building problems and video games. It was called the Google Games, a convivial way for the mostly computer science and engineering students to renew the Stanford-Berkeley rivalry. But behind the fun was a serious corporate recruiting event that underscores a rivalry no less intense: the tug of war for talent between Google and its competitors.

headline.main: In Fierce Competition, Google Finds Novel Ways to Feed Hiring Machine

docs.abstract: Google, Microsoft and Yahoo find themselves going after same job candidates or recruiting in one another's backyards; they are running up against myriad of start-up companies across Silicon Valley that have been pumped up with venture capital in recent years; these companies have expanded their recruiting arsenal far beyond traditional job fair to include growing number of events like technology lectures, cocktail parties, pizza parties, treasure hunts and programming contests, dubbed 'code jams' or 'hack days'; Google has been vacuuming talent wherever it can find it to keep fueling its torrid growth; its work force has roughly doubled every year for last several years, to more than 12,000 at end of March; Google is adding about 500 workers each month; its Web site lists nearly 800 open positions in San Francisco Bay Area alone; photos (L)
docs.snippet: Pizza parties, treasure hunts and programming contests are meant to create excitement around a company and impress potential recruits as young as college freshmen.

docs.lead_paragraph: IT'S kind of fitting that the first live-action 3-D movie expected to find its way to the modern multiplex after a preview at the Cannes Film Festival last week is a U2 concert film. The band's lead singer, Bono, is known for wearing shades, so it might seem downright participatory for the audience to don 3-D spectacles in order to have, as The Times's Sharon Waxman put it last week, ''the palpable experience of being present'' while U2 rocks out. In a more mainstream way, Hollywood bigwigs like James Cameron, Jeffrey Katzenberg, Steven Spielberg, Peter Jackson and Robert Zemeckis all have new 3-D projects in the works and are proclaiming the beginning of a bold new era for cinema.

headline.main: Millions of Addresses and Thousands of Sites, All Leading to One

docs.abstract: Millions of Addresses and Thousands of Sites, All Leading
docs.snippet: What Internet business has raised $120 million in financing in the last year and owns 725,000 Web sites?

docs.lead_paragraph: RECRUITING BATTLES As much of the high-tech industry is enjoying a renewed boom, the competition for top recruits in engineering and other fields is as intense as ever. Companies like Google, Microsoft and Yahoo find themselves going after the same candidates or recruiting in one another's backyards. At the same time, they are running up against a myriad of start-up companies across Silicon Valley. To lure talent, these companies have expanded their recruiting arsenal far beyond the traditional job fair to include events like technology lectures, cocktail parties, pizza parties, treasure hunts and programming contests, called ''code jams'' or ''hack days.'' [Page C1.] LOOKING FOR STARS Despite being the first and certainly the largest African-American cable channel, Black Entertainment Television has developed few of its own marketable stars and virtually no breakout programs. It relies on reruns, movies and music videos for the bulk of its lineup. The chief executive of BET, Debra L. Lee, has tried to reverse that trend, this year increasing the channel's production budget 50 percent and plunging into original programming with 16 new shows for the fall. [C1.] POLICEMAN, NOT A REPORTER David Cunningham, a prominent protester who heads the Anti-Poverty Committee in Vancouver, British Columbia, recently received a call from someone who said he was a reporter named Peter MacKay from the free daily tabloid 24 Hours Vancouver. But when Mr. Cunningham arrived outside a shopping mall for what he thought would be an interview, Peter MacKay turned out to be a plainclothes police officer who arrested him. Someone in the Vancouver Police Department thought the deception was a clever way to lure Mr. Cunningham, but the ruse provoked widespread criticism from civil rights and journalism groups. [C4.] HIGH ASPIRATIONS Though far from a household name in telecommunications, Altimo, the Russian telecommunications investment company, has aspirations of becoming a global power. But the problem it faces, some analysts say, is that at this point, Altimo has made few allies. If it is known beyond Russia at all, it is for its propensity to fight tenaciously in court and on corporate boards for its ambitions, some say. [C5.] THE MALE DIETER The face of dieting may be changing. Of the 72 million people dieting in the United States, 38 percent -- about 28 million -- are men, according to Marketdata Enterprises, a market research company. It estimates that the diet industry will be $58.7 billion this year. And NutriSystem has hired its first male spokesman, the former quarterback Dan Marino, and has started advertising in Sports Illustrated, Men's Health and ESPN magazine. [C3.] MAINSTREAM PROMOTION Mel Gibson's 2004 film ''The Passion of the Christ'' demonstrated to Hollywood just how many evangelical moviegoers there are and how much money can be made from them. Mindful of that market, Universal Pictures has teamed up with Grace Hill Media, a public relations firm that reaches out to religious groups, to publicize the mainstream film ''Evan Almighty.'' Scheduled for wide release on June 22, it stars Steve Carell as a politician who abandons Congress in order to build an ark, taking off on the story of Noah. [C3.] TALLYING GLIMPSES When the sleek yacht of the Luna Rossa team sailed away with a victory in the America's Cup semifinals, there were two vital results. The Italian crew eliminated the American team of BMW Oracle Racing with a 33-second lead. And fleeting glimpses of the flapping mainsails -- branded with logos of Telecom Italia Mobile and the broadband service Alice -- reached millions of television viewers. Those glimpses are now being counted down to the second, categorized by clear and partial visibility, tallied by major countries and then compared with the cost of traditional spot advertisements. [C2.] WEB PROPERTY DEVELOPER NameMedia, a privately held owner and developer of Web sites based in Waltham, Mass., is best seen as an online property developer, its chief executive, Kelly P. Conlin, said. Analysts suggest that NameMedia and its competitors could represent the next wave of Internet initial public offerings, while also providing a peek at a significant change in what people see when they stumble onto obscure Web properties. Bob Tedeschi, E-Commerce Report. [C5.] THE TOUCH-UP In a situation not as emotionally charged as when Time magazine darkened O.J. Simpson's mug shot on its cover a decade ago, no fewer than three magazines were reacting to claims last week that they had doctored their covers -- and one retouched celebrity even cried foul. [C4.] A PULITZER AWARD Often the writing and photography that win Pulitzer Prizes require heroic efforts. For one recipient, Jahangir Razmi , the process of receiving the award also took 27 years. In 1979, Mr. Razmi stood near executioners as they shot Kurdish prisoners in Sanandaj, Iran. One picture was picked up by the wire service United Press International. To protect Mr. Razmi, his name was never printed. But after decades of keeping silent, Mr. Razmi allowed his name to appear in a December 2006 article in The Wall Street Journal, which prompted the Pulitzer Prize Board to seek out Mr. Razmi to award him the prize in person. [C4.] VIEWER REVOLT The cancellation of the CBS series ''Jericho'' has led to a viewer revolt that has included not only the usual petition drives, but also the delivery of tons of nuts (mostly walnuts, but also peanuts and pecans) to the two responsible CBS executives. [C4.] THE PRETEEN MARKET With a faithful audience in the millions, magazines for the early teenage years are in overdrive, bolstered by last year's enthusiasm for new stars from the Disney Channel's hit ''High School Musical,'' which made household names not only of Zac Efron and Corbin Bleu, but also of Ashley Tisdale and Vanessa Anne Hudgens. [C1.]

docs.lead_paragraph: FROM New York to Washington, government suddenly seems to be in the business of promoting alternative energy. Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg of New York announced last week that the city's taxi fleet would convert to hybrids by 2012. In this year's State of the Union address, President Bush called for the nation to replace 20 percent of gasoline use with ethanol in 10 years. The government talk is being backed by action and policy. The federal government offers a 51-cent-a-gallon tax credit to ethanol producers and maintains a 54-cent-a-gallon tariff on ethanol imported from Brazil. More than 20 states have so-called renewable portfolio standards, which mandate that utilities derive a fixed percentage of their power from renewable sources.

headline.main: With Help, Could Ethanol Be the Next Internet?

docs.lead_paragraph: WHAT do you think of the latest video on YouTube? Wait. Don't answer that, or at least don't answer with words. Because almost the instant you start to talk about one of the beautiful, puzzling videos that pervade the site that Google acquired last fall for $1.65 billion, you reveal that you're missing the point. Really the only authentic response to a YouTube video is another YouTube video -- the so-called ''video response.'' YouTube appeared in February 2005, when it was modestly billed as a site on which people could swap personal videos. Since then, however, its video-response feature, which essentially allows users to converse through video, has managed to convene partisans of almost every field of human endeavor, creating video clusters that begin with an opening video, and snowball as fans and detractors are moved to respond with videos of their own. In answer to a lousy, stammering video, say, a real YouTuber doesn't just comment, ''You idiot -- I could do that blindfolded!'' He blindfolds himself, gets out his video-capable Canon PowerShot and uploads the results.

headline.main: The Many Tribes of YouTube

docs.lead_paragraph: When Estonian authorities began removing a bronze statue of a World War II-era Soviet soldier from a park in this bustling Baltic seaport last month, they expected violent street protests by Estonians of Russian descent. They also knew from experience that ''if there are fights on the street, there are going to be fights on the Internet,'' said Hillar Aarelaid, the director of Estonia's Computer Emergency Response Team. After all, for people here the Internet is almost as vital as running water; it is used routinely to vote, file their taxes, and, with their cellphones, to shop or pay for parking.

headline.main: After Computer Siege in Estonia, War Fears Turn to Cyberspace

docs.abstract: Estonian authorities are forced to defend their nation from data flood that could be called first war in cyberspace; decision by authorities to remove bronze statue of World War II-era Soviet soldier from park in Tallinn prompted violent street protests by Estonians of Russian descent, and then monthlong computer campaign that came close to shutting down country's digital infrastructure, clogging Web sites of president, prime minister, Parliament and other government agencies, staggering Estonia's biggest bank and overwhelming sites of several daily newspapers; Estonian authorities accuse Russian authorities of instigating attacks, noting Internet address involved in attacks belongs to official working in Pres Vladimir V Putin's administration; Russian government denies any involvement; computer security experts from NATO, European Union, United States and Israel have converged on Tallinn to offer help and to learn what they can about cyberwar in digital age; photos; map; timeline of data-flooding attacks (M)

Ms. Kalin-Casey, who manages an apartment building here with her husband, John Casey, was a bit shaken when she tried a new feature in Google's map service called Street View. She typed in her address and the screen showed a street-level view of her building. Watson, who jointly discovered the structure of DNA in 1953, has been deciphered, marking what scientists believe is the gateway to an impending era of personalized genomic medicine. But there is uncertainty over whether lawmakers in Congress will extend the tax benefits that encourage companies to invest in wind power. [C1.] PICTURES, FOLLOWED BY WORDS -- A new online feature of Google Maps that offers panoramic ground-level photographs of miles of streets around San Francisco, New York, Las Vegas, Miami and Denver is stirring up a debate over privacy concerns on the Web. [C1.] PUBLISHERS SEEKING BLOCKBUSTER -- In the absence of a new Harry Potter book or a blockbuster by Dan Brown, the publishing industry struggled to sell more copies last year than it did the year before, according to a report to be released today by the Book Industry Study Group, a publishing trade association. [C3.] QUESTIONS OVER MAN WITH TB -- The man with a dangerous form of tuberculosis who flew to Europe for his wedding and honeymoon was identified as Andrew Speaker, 31, a lawyer in Atlanta, who homeland security officials said entered the country when a customs agent who knew Mr. Speaker was being sought by health authorities let him pass. Congress plans to hold hearings on the way the case has been handled. [A1.] DELL TO LAY OFF 10% OF WORKERS -- Dell said that it would lay off 10 percent of its 88,100 employees over the next 12 months as it tries to increase profit. [C3.] WACHOVIA BUYS A. G. EDWARDS -- The Wachovia Corporation swallowed up A. G. Edwards in a $6.8 billion cash and stock deal that highlights the continued consolidation of the retail brokerage sector. [C5.] FINES PAID IN BACKDATING CASES -- Two technology companies, Brocade Communications Systems and Mercury Interactive, became the first two companies to pay fines to settle federal accusations of civil fraud in connection with backdated stock options. Brocade has agreed to pay $7 million and Mercury is paying $28 million. [C8.] WELLPOINT OUSTS FINANCIAL CHIEF -- WellPoint, the biggest American health insurer, ousted its chief financial officer after an external investigation revealed he violated its code of conduct. The board named its chief accounting officer, Wayne S. DeVeydt, to replace the finance chief, David C. Colby, effective immediately. [C6.] GREEN ISSUES AND AUTOMAKERS -- Labor and management in the auto industry are often at odds, but they have agreed on something critics have been telling them for years: Detroit must act to reduce its vehicles' impact on the environment. [C3.] N.J. COURT RULES ON WAL-MART SUIT -- In a setback for Wal-Mart, the New Jersey Supreme Court ruled that a lawsuit claiming that the company refused to allow workers to take rest breaks and meal breaks could proceed as a class action on behalf of nearly 80,000 current and former Wal-Mart employees. [C7.] CONGRESS TAKING UP TAX SHELTERS -- Congress is taking another close look at reining in questionable tax shelters that have deprived the government of hundreds of billions of dollars in taxes in recent years. [C5.] ECONOMIC GROWTH RATE IS CUT -- The Commerce Department revised the broadest indicator of economic strength, measuring all goods and services produced in the United States, to show a 0.6 percent advance over the first three months of the year. [C3.] 'MISCONDUCT' BY 2 CHINESE FIRMS -- Chinese regulators acknowledged that two Chinese companies had ''engaged in some misconduct'' in the way they labeled and sold a poisonous ingredient that ended up in cold medicine, killing at least 100 people in Panama last year. But the regulators said primary responsibility for the deaths rested with traders in Spain and Panama. [A6.] ONLINE RETIREMENT -- As life spans lengthen, experts on aging say it is more important than ever to prepare for the physical and psychological aspects of retirement. A special section is at nytimes.com/retirement. BUSINESS OF GREEN -- Consumer products are beginning to carry details about their environmental impact, and restaurant owners are finding ways to handle garbage with less affect on the environment. Those articles and more are in a special section at nytimes.com/business. Business Briefing Articles on these developments are available at nytimes.com/business. The Justice Department approved Monsanto's $1.5 billion acquisition of the cotton company Delta and Pine Land, but required both companies to sell assets related to cottonseed production. (AP)

docs.lead_paragraph: THE story of the college dropout who became the world's richest man still has the power to inspire us. It affirms our deeply engrained view that rejecting the received wisdom (do my own thing!) is a path to creativity and wealth. As Walt Whitman famously wrote 150 years ago, ''I celebrate myself, and sing myself.'' In our individualistic country, the strong, lone voice is often viewed as the animating force behind every kind of success.

docs.lead_paragraph: THESE days, Google seems to be doing everything, everywhere. It takes pictures of your house from outer space, copies rare Sanskrit books in India, charms its way onto Madison Avenue, picks fights with Hollywood and tries to undercut Microsoft's software dominance. But at its core, Google remains a search engine. And its search pages, blue hyperlinks set against a bland, white background, have made it the most visited, most profitable and arguably the most powerful company on the Internet. Google is the homework helper, navigator and yellow pages for half a billion users, able to find the most improbable needles in the world's largest haystack of information in just the blink of an eye.

headline.main: Inside the Black Box

docs.abstract: Article on work of Amit Singhal and hundreds of other Google engineers who are constantly tweaking search engine in quest to close gap between what users are seeking and what they are able to find; Google believes that its ability to decrease number of times it leaves searchers disappointed is crucial to fending off competition from Yahoo and Microsoft and preserving advertising gold mine that search represents; chart; photos (L)
docs.snippet: Google’s top minds offer a peek inside the algorithm that provides search results for half a billion users.

docs.lead_paragraph: Bill Hambrecht is a rich old Wall Street guy who has made his money tilting at windmills and disrupting the establishment. ''That's what I do,'' he says. ''It's fun.'' Almost a decade ago, at 62, he founded WR Hambrecht + Company, whose fundamental premise is that companies don't need to use Wall Street investment bankers -- and pay their outrageous fees -- to go public. Hambrecht + Company has since become so threatening to traditional underwriters that they often refuse to be involved in any I.P.O. in which his firm takes part. And now, at an age when most people are well into retirement, he has decided to tackle the establishment again. This time, though, the establishment isn't Wall Street. It's the National Football League. Bill Hambrecht, you see, is starting up a professional football league. So far, he and his partner, Tim Armstrong, a senior executive at Google, have pledged $2 million each. They've hired a C.E.O. and a C.O.O., both of whom cut their teeth at the National Basketball Association. They've got a name: the United Football League. And they've lined up a wealthy, well-known businessman as their first owner: Mark Cuban, the billionaire who owns the N.B.A.'s Dallas Mavericks. Like Hambrecht, Cuban loves nothing more than confronting the status quo.

headline.main: THE BUSINESS: First and Long -- Very Long

docs.snippet: Bill Hambrecht, who has made a name and fortune for himself by rattling the Wall Street establishment, will set his sights on the N.F.L. when he tries to launch a rival professional football league in 2008.

Jon Rubinstein, a former Apple executive who ran its iPod division, is also planning to join Palm as its executive chairman as part of the transaction.

docs.lead_paragraph: The plot as painted by law enforcement officials was cataclysmic: A home-grown Islamic terrorist had in mind detonating fuel storage tanks and pipelines and setting fire to Kennedy International Airport, not to mention a substantial swath of Queens. ''Had the plot been carried out, it could have resulted in unfathomable damage, deaths and destruction,'' Roslynn R. Mauskopf, the United States attorney in Brooklyn, said in a news release that announced charges against four men. She added at a news conference, ''The devastation that would be caused had this plot succeeded are just unthinkable.''

headline.main: Plot Suspects Described as Short on Cash And a Long Way From Realizing Goals

docs.abstract: United States attorney's office announces charges against four men, led by Russell M Defreitas, accused of plotting to detonate pipelines at Kennedy International Airport, saying that devastation would have been massive; actual criminal complaint, however, suggests that plot was longer on evil intent than on operational capability; one official likes four to 'gang that couldn't shoot seeming gap between rhetoric of announcement and reality of threat could reflect change in approach among law enforcement officials, with prosecutors and investigators needing to pounce sooner than in past, with less evidence, on even lowest-level terrorist threats; photos (M)
docs.snippet: The would-be terrorists who plotted to detonate facilities at Kennedy International Airport seem to have had more evil intent than operational capability.

docs.lead_paragraph: John Updike would not be pleased. A year ago that literary lion elicited a standing ovation in a banquet hall full of booksellers when he exhorted them to ''defend your lonely forts'' against a digital future of free book downloads and snippets of text. But this year, at BookExpo America, the publishing industry's annual convention that ended yesterday, the battering ram of technology was back.

docs.lead_paragraph: GRANDPA lived through the Depression, and life thereafter was indelibly shaped by haunting memories of soup kitchens and hobos. Similarly, the digerati of Silicon Valley endured the 1990s dot-com bubble, and since then have lived with the psychic shock of its ignoble end. The average valley entrepreneur tends to spot bubbles everywhere, much the way granddad feared financial ruin every time a grandchild carelessly scraped leftover food into the trash.

headline.main: In Silicon Valley, the Crash Seems Like Just Yesterday

docs.abstract: Entrepreneurial spirit is robust in Silicon Valley but industry workers are also displaying insecurity and anxiety about repeat of 1990s dot-com bubble; it is unclear whether there is really bubble about to pop or whether Silicon Valley is just suffering from post-traumatic stress; once again, industry is abuzz about preposterous prices some are paying to own small slice of start-up that has no clear plan for making profit; some experts say venture capitalists are investing smaller fraction of money than they committed during earlier boom; others say that boom-bust cycle is inherent part of tech innovation; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: A once cocksure region is displaying a deep-seated insecurity  raising the question of whether there’s really a bubble about to pop or whether Silicon Valley is just suffering from post-traumatic stress.

docs.lead_paragraph: Four men, including a onetime airport cargo handler and a former member of the Parliament of Guyana, were charged yesterday with plotting to blow up fuel tanks, terminal buildings and the web of fuel lines running beneath Kennedy International Airport. One of the suspects was taken into custody in Brooklyn and two others were detained in Trinidad, the authorities said, while the fourth man was still at large.

headline.main: 4 Men Accused of Plot to Blow Up Kennedy Airport Terminals and Fuel Lines

docs.abstract: Federal authorities charge Trinidadian Kareem Ibrahim, Guyanese Abdul Kadir and Abdel Nur and naturalized United States citizen Russell M Defreitas with plot to blow up Kennedy International Airport in New York City by igniting fuel lines running beneath it; Defreitas was once cargo handler at airport; authorities say safety values would have almost certainly prevented igniting of fuel lines and tanks at airport; say men traveled to Guyana and Trinidad to seek approval and get financial backing from Trinidad-based extremist Muslim group called Jamaat al-Muslimeen; photos; chart (M)
docs.snippet: A former cargo handler and three other men were charged with plotting to blow up terminal buildings, fuel tanks and pipelines.

docs.lead_paragraph: A decade ago the Minnesota Board of Medical Practice accused Dr. Faruk Abuzzahab of a ''reckless, if not willful, disregard'' for the welfare of 46 patients, 5 of whom died in his care or shortly afterward. The board suspended his license for seven months and restricted it for two years after that. But Dr. Abuzzahab, a Minneapolis psychiatrist, is still overseeing the testing of drugs on patients and is being paid by pharmaceutical companies for the work. At least a dozen have paid him for research or marketing since he was disciplined.

headline.main: After Sanctions, Doctors Get Drug Company Pay

docs.abstract: Minnesota Board of Medical Practice in 1997 suspended license of Dr Faruk Abuzzahab after 5 patients died in his care or shortly afterward, yet from 1997 to 2005, several drug companies hired him to conduct multiple drug trials and paid him over $55,000 in speaking and consulting fees; examination of Minnesota's records on drug company payments to doctors found that from 1997 to 2005, at least 103 doctors who had been disciplined or criticized by state medical board received total of $1.7 million from drug makers; cases of David Olson and Susan Endersbe, patients of Abuzzahab who committed suicide, noted; chart; photos (M)
docs.snippet: Many doctors who were sanctioned by a medical board were later paid for research by drug makers.

docs.lead_paragraph: RECEPTIVENESS to new technologies often seems related to age. For example, more 13-year-olds than 63-year-olds understand phrases like ''Waz ?'' and ''N2MH.'' (In case you're over 13, those expressions are cellphonese for, ''What's up?'' and ''Not too much here.'') So it was with pride that I watched my parents ''get'' the magic of digital photography after our family reunion last summer. On the final night, I treated them to a laptop slide show of our week together. They dug it.

docs.lead_paragraph: DISPUTE OVER AVANDIA STUDY -- GlaxoSmithKline says that preliminary results of a clinical trial provide reassurance that Avandia, its treatment for diabetes, does not raise the risk of a heart attack. But influential doctors argued that the data did nothing to alleviate their concerns about the drug's heart risks. [Page A1.] GlaxoSmithKline won praise when it focused on African-Americans in marketing Avandia. But now that Avandia is dogged by safety questions, Glaxo's advertising strategy could end up working against the company. Advertising. [C1.] PLAYING AT HOME -- Chatting with friends and playing with dolls, all via the Internet -- millions of children and adolescents are spending hours on interactive play sites, which are aimed mainly at girls. [C1.] TIPTOEING INTO U.S. MARKET -- Britain's largest retailer, Tesco, is finally ready to enter the American market, beginning with a relatively modest string of neighborhood convenience stores called Fresh and Easy, in Los Angeles, Phoenix, Las Vegas and San Diego. [C1.] EBAY SELLING RADIO AIRTIME -- The auction giant eBay said it would begin selling radio airtime to advertisers starting Wednesday, expanding into a business that Google entered last year. [C3.] IN A SELLING MOOD -- Signs mounted that Federal Reserve is in no hurry to lower interest rates, leading to a sell-off in the markets. [C3.] The stock market posted its first decline in a week after bond yields surged to a nine-month high. [C11.] F.T.C. ACTS TO BLOCK MERGER -- The Federal Trade Commission said that it would file a legal complaint today to block the proposed merger of Wild Oats Markets and Whole Foods Market, arguing that the deal would lead to higher prices for natural and organic products in markets where the two chains now compete. [C1.] MANURE PLANT GENERATES DEBATE -- Tons of turkey manure and a new $200 million power plant that burns the manure to produce electricity can be found in Benton, Minn. The power plant is the first of its kind in the country, but it is also the target of environmentalists who question the earth-friendliness of the operation. [A1.] MEDIA COMPETITION IN MEXICO -- Mexico's Supreme Court struck down crucial provisions of a media law, in a defeat for Mexico's television duopoly that sends a message favoring greater economic competition. [C2.] MARKETS THAT ARE QUICK TO REACT -- The Chinese government is learning the dangers of intervening in stock markets, as policy shifts by the government and even speculation of policy shifts have led to sharp swings in share prices on the Shanghai and Shenzhen stock markets. [C9.] WAGONER URGES PATIENCE -- Rick Wagoner, the chairman and chief executive of General Motors, faced more than two hours of criticism from shareholders at the annual meeting, but he countered that the company had made major progress in turning around its fortunes last year. ''We're taking the profound actions necessary to transform the company for the long haul,'' Mr. Wagoner, above, said. Shareholders expressed their frustration. ''We've done turnarounds so many times we're going in circles,'' said one. [C5.] HBO'S NEW LINEUP -- HBO announced a new lineup of four top corporate officers to succeed Chris Albrecht, the chief executive who resigned last month. The group will be led by Bill Nelson as the chairman and chief executive. [C3.] DOW JONES WORKERS SEEK BUYER -- The main union of the Dow Jones & Company employees, hoping to head off a takeover by Rupert Murdoch, is shopping around for another bidder and has begun talks with aides to Ronald W. Burkle, a California billionaire, union officials and others said. [C4.] ENTICING SHOPPERS IN MAINE -- Freeport, Me., recently approved the development of a $45 million open-air pedestrian-friendly ''lifestyle center,'' basically a shopping center without walls, to help keep pace with retailers moving into nearby cities in Maine. [C7.] SERVICE INDUSTRY GROWING -- Service businesses, which make up almost 90 percent of the economy, expanded at an unexpectedly high rate last month, a sign the economy is strengthening. [C3.] HE OWNS THE HOTEL -- Laurence S. Geller, the chief executive of Strategic Hotels and Resorts, a real estate investment trust that owns 20 high-end hotels in North America and Europe, represents a new breed of hands-on owners who push managers to wring more profit out of their assets. [C6.] $29 MILLION IN RESTITUTION TO CA -- A former sales chief at CA, the software maker, has agreed to pay $29.7 million in restitution after pleading guilty last year to criminal charges in a scheme to raise the company's quarterly revenue artificially through backdated sales contracts.[C3.] ONLINE I.B.M. SETTLES WITH S.E.C. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission said yesterday that I.B.M. had settled a case in which it had been accused of misleading investors by overestimating the impact of stock-based compensation expenses on quarterly earnings in 2005. docs.lead_paragraph: By the time a police van pulled up outside a Morningside Heights apartment on April 14 where a 23-year-old Columbia University graduate student had been tortured for 19 hours, her assailant was long gone. But inside the van, laptop computers were humming with a wireless link to a high-tech nerve center in Police Headquarters, next to the Manhattan approach to the Brooklyn Bridge. The student survived the ordeal, and when an arrest was made five days later, the case was considered another success for the New York Police Department's sophisticated anticrime computer network, which matched a nickname to a suspect. Now two years old, the technical initiative has evolved into one of the department's most potent crime-fighting tools.

headline.main: From Database to Crime Scene: Network Is Potent Police Weapon

docs.abstract: Real Time Crime Center, New York City Police Dept's sophisticated computer network, is one of its most potent crime-fighting tools; core is search engine that quickly relays information to officers in field from high-tech array of data feeds and displays; Center also information that is otherwise scattered and without context; companion fleet of 11 computer-equipped vans gather witness information at crime scenes; police officials say Center's databases will include law enforcement records dating back 25 years by fall, which worries some civil libertarians; several cases solved by Center noted; photos (M)
docs.snippet: Now two years old, a police search engine has evolved into one of the department’s most potent crime-fighting tools.

docs.lead_paragraph: INVESTORS who want to add a margin of safety when searching for hot growth stocks may want to consider a grading system developed by Partha S. Mohanram, an associate professor at Columbia University's business school. Professor Mohanram says that his method can't reliably pinpoint the next Google, but that it may help investors avoid some money-losers. For individual investors, the main insight of his work may be that stocks whose prices far outstrip the net value of their assets are unlikely to outperform the overall market. Prudent investors would be advised to do their homework and avoid such risky bets.

headline.main: To Pick Winners, Start by Weeding Out the Losers

docs.lead_paragraph: Nearly a decade after the government began its landmark effort to break up Microsoft, the Bush administration has sharply changed course by repeatedly defending the company both in the United States and abroad against accusations of anticompetitive conduct, including the recent rejection of a complaint by Google. The retrenchment reflects a substantially different view of antitrust policy, as well as a recognition of major changes in the marketplace. The battlefront among technology companies has shifted from computer desktop software, a category that Microsoft dominates, to Internet search and Web-based software programs that allow users to bypass products made by Microsoft, the world's largest software maker.

headline.main: MICROSOFT FINDS LEGAL DEFENDER IN JUSTICE DEPT.
